SUMMARY: Healthy Hampshire organized a walk audit of Route 202 in Belchertown, covering the area from the town common to the Eastern Hampshire District Courthouse. The audit aimed to foster awareness of infrastructure elements that contribute to the walking environment, evaluate the safety and quality of the route, and recommend improvements. It involved 18 older adult volunteers, the Planning Director, and the Conservation Commissioner, with participant recruitment by the Senior Center and Healthy Hampshire staff.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Implement traffic calming techniques​ to slow traffic down.
- Increase safety and visibility of crosswalks by redesigning them to be truly accessible to everyone (raised crosswalks, blinking lights, curb ramps, detectable warning strips, etc.).
-Tighten the turning radius at each intersection and driveway ​to slow turning traffic and increase pedestrian sightlines, visibility and length of crossings.
- Make sidewalks clearly continuous across curb cuts and driveways ​using continuous materials such as concrete to indicate the appropriate path for pedestrians.
- Sidewalks should always be added ​in this area when there is new construction.
- Connect sidewalks to walking and recreational trails​.
- Plan for bicyclist and pedestrians first​ when renovating any street or road.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Increase safety and visibility of crosswalks by repainting.
- Install push-button pedestrian activated signals.
- Add benches, spruce up green spaces, and plant shade trees​to make it more inviting.
- Consolidate driveways or narrow driveways ​to reduce the number of curb cuts.
- Establish a dedicated sidewalk maintenance budget ​to repair/replace sidewalk in this corridor.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Route 202 (State St & Maple St)
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Bike or Bus, Connectivity

SUMMARY: The Hilltowns CDC, Healthy Hampshire, and WalkMass are leading a 5-year grant project to improve walkability in Hilltowns Village Centers, including Blandford, through walk audits and infrastructure planning. Blandford is simultaneously working on a Resilient Master Plan and Open Space and Recreation Plan, prioritizing improved walking connections between key destinations like Watson Park, the Town Common, and the library. Plans include redesigning the Town Common, expanding Veteran’s Memorial Park, and improving connectivity to enhance village center walkability and accessibility for all ages.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Improve safety and visibility of existing pedestrian crossings within the village center.
- Consider redesign of the North Street/Rt 23 intersection to a T intersection to provide a safe crossing for people moving between the Historical Society building and the parking area.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Reduce traffic speeds on Route 23 through the Blandford village center.
- Consider pedestrian wayfinding signage along walking route(s) to advertise their existence and promote walking in the village center.
- Ensure that the walking route, village center and Bicentennial Park are well maintained.
- Identify a safe crossing location across North Street to connect the White Church to the Hill Cemetery and Town Common.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Russel Stage Rd., Main St., North St., & South Part of Watson Park Walking Trail
THEMES: Comfort , "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Connectivity, Accessibility, Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: In partnership with WalkUP Roslindale, a community advocacy group, a walk audit was conducted in Roslindale Square to assess walking conditions and develop recommendations for the Boston Transportation Department. While the Square’s pre-WWII design fosters a walkable and lively atmosphere, issues such as confusing one-way street configurations, high vehicle volumes, and insufficient crosswalks and WALK signals were identified. These factors detract from pedestrian safety despite the area's vibrant street life and active local economy. The audit highlights opportunities to improve walkability and enhance Roslindale as a safe and inviting neighborhood for all.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider converting one-way streets to two-way.
- Consider safer placement of bicycle lanes.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
-  Increase the number and safety of street crossings and improve WALK signal timings.
- Remove selected in-street parking spaces to improve pedestrian visibility in the immediate vicinity of crosswalks.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: South St, Washington St, Corinth St, & Belgrade Ave
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Bike or Bus

SUMMARY: WalkBoston aided students from Codman Academy Charter School with identifying the safety benefits of closing Epping St after a student was struck and seriously injured on the one block, one lane roadway bordering the academy in 2014.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS: - Epping St should be closed, and the campus should be extended across Epping St to improve student and staff safety and to cretae a more cohesive campus.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS: - Implement measures to stop drivers from turning abruptly onto Epping St to avoid the red traffic light at the Norfolk/Talbot intersection.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Epping St, Norfolk St, Talbot St
THEMES: Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: The goal of the Walk Audit is to identify safe and easy walking access from a proposed new development on East Cottage Street in Dorchester to the shops, services, and Uphams Corner Station, located four blocks southeast on the Fairmount Commuter Line. The 2.75-acre development includes commercial/industrial space along East Cottage Street and 88–92 units of affordable housing set back behind the commercial space. Despite its proximity to Uphams Corner, there are no walking connections between the development and the neighborhood center, commuter rail station, or bus lines along Dudley Street and Columbia Road.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider creating a roundabout at the East Cottage/Norfolk/Humphreys intersection to reduce vehicle speeds and improve pedestrian crossings.
- Incorporate additional pedestrian pathways within the East Cottage Development for better neighborhood connectivity.
- Plan for expanded street infrastructure improvements once the development is fully realized, ensuring pedestrian connections to other nearby areas.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Create a walking connection at Harrow Street to the proposed East Cottage Development, using public land where Harrow Street meets the development site.
- Tighten curb radii at the East Cottage/Norfolk/Humphreys intersection to reduce crossing distances and improve pedestrian safety.
- Paint visible, ladder-style crosswalks at the East Cottage/Norfolk/Humphreys intersection for better driver awareness.
- Widen the sidewalk on East Cottage Street to ensure enough space for pedestrians, especially around the Diamond Window and Doors area.
- Construct a sidewalk on Hillsboro Street to improve pedestrian access to other parts of the neighborhood.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Harrow St, East Cottage St, Hillsboro St, Intersection of the East Cottage /Norfolk/Humphreys
THEMES: Connectivity, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: A group of Mattapan seniors, WalkMass, the Elderly Commission, local organizations, city agencies, and elected officials conducted an Age-Friendly walk audit starting at ABCD Mattapan. After a “Ped 101” presentation on pedestrian infrastructure and a discussion on local walking challenges, the group split into two teams to assess traffic and walking conditions: one at the Blue Hill Ave, River St, and Cummins Hwy intersection, and the other along Blue Hill Ave through the business district. They reconvened at ABCD to discuss strategies for improving Mattapan Square's walking environment.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Develop a multi-stakeholder working group (potentially including Boston Transportation Department [BTD], Public Works Department [PWD], Department of Conservation and Recreation [DCR], Town of Milton, Mattapan Food and Fitness Coalition and others) to ensure coordination under the Age-Friendly umbrella of different projects in/around Mattapan Square.
- Reach out to State Representatives and Senators (Rep. Cullinane, Rep. Holmes, Sen. Forry) to follow up on the $500,000 earmarked for a traffic study in Mattapan Square, which may address roadway design and signal phasing issues.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Address WALK signal timing issues.
- Balance the need for seniors to have places to sit (benches, bus shelters, etc.) with concerns about public safety and loitering. 
- Plant shade trees at several locations, such as the church at the corner of Cummins Hwy and River St.
- Add more seating in areas near Fairway Street that have good tree shading and room for benches.
- Add more trees and greenery in areas that currently lack it – there’s too much brick and concrete in the Square.
- Conduct a parking srudy.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Blue Hill Ave, River St, Cummins Hwy, Blue Hill Ave, & Babson St
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, Policy, Age Friendly

SUMMARY: On September 14, 2016, Urban Edge and WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment in Egleston Square to examine pedestrian infrastructure conditions in the highly trafficked Main St corridor. The intention for the assessment was to help lead to on-the-ground build environment changes in Egleston Square that enable active and sustainable transportation for all. Beforehand, WalkBoston and partner organizations Boston Cyclists Union and LivableStreets submitted a joint letter to the Boston Planning and Development Agency (BPDA) outlining numerous recommendations for enhancing pedestrian and bicycling infrastructure in the study area. After the walk assessment was conducted, several of the recommendations from the assessment were then presented to the Egleston Square Neighborhood Association (ESNA).
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider eliminating right-turn lanes (potentially in conjunction with curb extensions) and/or banning left turns; consider gathering traffic counts to determine the implications of such changes and how traffic might be diverted to other streets.
- Implement a road diet on Columbus Ave (reduce from two travel lanes to one).
- Consider adding "Don't Block the Box" at the intersection of Washington St and School St as well as other heavily congested locations.
- Consider changing traffic circulation patterns around Egleston Square (e.g. converting two-way segment on School St between Washington St and Weld Ave to one-way, banning/blocking left turns from Columbus Ave onto Weld Ave); consider gathering traffic counts to determine the implications of such changes and how traffic might be diverted to other streets.
- Address collision hazards at Westminster Ave and wardman Road where Westminster Ave bottlenecks due to parked cars.
- Address curb drainage issues at Waldren Road and Westminster Ave.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add crosswalks across streets and intersections (e.g. Washington St, Columbus Ave); add high-visibility signage to enhance pedestrian safety; daylight the crosswalk to improve visibility.
- Use curb extensions to reduce crossing distances and calm traffic at the Washington St/Columbus Ave.
- Reconfigure signal timings to create more predictable WALK signal cycle; consider making WALK cycle automatic, thus eliminating the need for pedestrians to push a button.
- Consider moving the crosswalk across Washington St at Atherton St from the south side of the intersection to the north side, thus enhancing visibility between pedestrians in the crosswalk and drivers turning right onto Washington St from Columbus Ave.
- Enhance the mid-block crossing outside Egleston Branch Library by adding more visible pedestrian signage in the median and/or a flashing beacon.
- Add a mid-block crossing with visible pedestrian signage and/or a flashing beacon across Columbus Ave at the Rafael Hernandez School.
- Add WALK signals to all sides of the crosswalks across Columbus Ave at Bragdon St and remove obstructions in the medians to facilitate access for seniors and people with disabilities.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Columbus Ave, Dixwell St, School St, Washington St, Westminster Ave, Waldren Rd
THEMES: Accessibility, Age Friendly , Comfort & Safety, Policy

SUMMARY: East Boston seniors, WalkMass, the City of Boston Elderly Commission, and local organizations conducted an Age-Friendly walk audit near the East Boston Neighborhood Health Center in Maverick Square. Part of the Age-Friendly Walking initiative, the audit focused on the Meridian Street corridor between Maverick Square and Central Square, identifying strengths like vibrant pedestrian activity and streetscape elements, along with challenges such as unsafe street crossings, traffic congestion, and construction impacts.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Create a safe pedestrian crossing to the Maverick Blue Line station at the northernmost edge of Maverick Square.
- Create safer crossings along Meridian Street by adding bumpouts/curb extensions, daylight crosswalks to enhance visibility, in-street pedestrian crossing signs in crosswalks across Meridian Street, additional signage, and raised crosswalks.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Create safer pedestrian crossings and walkways around Central Square.
- Enhance the public realm along the Meridian Street corridor. 
- Enhance Harborwalk Access at Liberty Plaza.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Mavericlk Sq, Meridian St, Saratoga St, Border St, Liberty Plaza, & Harborwalk
THEMES: Accessibility, Comfort & Safety, Connectivity, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: WalkBoston met with Mr. Sam Balto, the physical education teacher and safety coach at the Ellis School, to review safety conditions around the school on September 14, 2017 after the school expressed concern about the safety of children walking to school. It was observed that crossing the streets was unsafe for children because drivers regularly drove at speeds going up to 35 mph, especially at Walnut Ave.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Daylight street corners and mid-block crossings so drivers have a clear view of pedestrians. This is especially important at some intersections because Walnut St has many curves.
- Create curb extensions and/or speed table on Walnut to slow vehicles and make people waiting to corss more visible to people driving.
- Consider a bump out at the Cobden/Walnut intersection to improve visibility; install a median island to control cars making short lefts and require them to go around it.
- Consider a mini traffic circle at the Walnut/Holworthy/Crawford intersection, or bump out the northwest corner to make the turn more of a right angle and remove parking near the crosswalk to make the stop sign and people waiting to cross more visible to drivers.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint the word SCHOOL on the pavement near the school and add school zone signs to better indicate to drivers they are entering the school zone.
- Install a speed feedback board along Walnut St.
- Use V types of crossing at Ruthven/Walnut to make a larger crosswalk area; a similar V crossing has been installed at Longwood/Riverway in the Longwood Medical District.
- Remove a parking space on each side of the Ruthven/Walnut intersection to daylight the crosswalk.
- Change the angle of the school zone sign to make it clear the school zone is down Walnut Ave.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Ruthven St, Westminster St, Walnut Ave, Holworthy St, Crawford St
THEMES: Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Youth

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit along Dorchester St to observe existing pedestrian conditions. When making observations and suggestions, the participants had in mind a survey of South Boston residents conducted by LivableStreets about improving transportation safety in the neighborhood. These residents were asked questions about pedestrian safety, and many of their responses matched with the recommendations the audit participants had for Dorchester St.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Build bump outs to shorten crossing distances, ensure that parking is pulled back to daylight intersections, and narrow Dorchester Street.
- Investigate and possibly modify zoning/site plan review regulations to reduce/prevent the addition of new curb cuts for driveways on Dorchester Street with particular attention to closely spaced curb cuts and curb cuts to ramped garage entries, both of which are hazards to pedestrians.
- Put Dorchester Street on a road diet by narrowing the street to one-lane in each direction with intermittent left-turn lanes if needed to manage traffic. The new design would include safe pedestrian crossings, additional sidewalk width and tree planting, bicycle accommodation, and adequate curb space for deliveries, bus stops,
and TNCs (Uber/Lyft).
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Provide daylighting for all Dorchester Street and side street crosswalks by removing
parking spaces adjacent to the crosswalks where there is approaching traffic. The distance required should be determined by the sight lines – the curve of the streets will require different distances. Physical barriers such as flex posts will be needed to ensure that drivers do not park adjacent to the crosswalks.
- Provide additional mid-street “Yield to Pedestrian” signs, and where possible find merchants or residents to adopt the signs and put them back in place if they are pushed aside or tell the Public Works Department if replacements are necessary.
- Adjacent to places serving vulnerable users such as senior housing (Marian Manor) or schools, implement 20-MPH safety zones.
- Investigate the addition of parking-protected bike lanes which would both improve bike safety and significantly narrow the very wide street and make it easier to cross.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Dorchester St
THEMES: Age Friendly , "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Bike or Bus, Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit along Medford St from Chelsea St to the Schrafft's Center with the purpose of identifying opportunities and challenges to creating stronger connections between the Charlestown community and the Mystic River waterfront and Harborwalk.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Provide better connections from Medford St and the neighborhood to the existing portions of the Harborwalk.
- Add benches and shade along the Harborwalk for the comfort of pedestrians and enourage walking.
- Prevent cars from parking close to crosswalks to improve visibility for both pedestrians and drivers.
- Repair sidewalks and curb ramps in disrepair along Medford St.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add signs and consider landscaping along Medford St to open up the locations of direct connection to the Harborwalk.
- Evaluate landscape improvements to soften the Medford St edge and make it more attractive for walking.
- Implement more crosswalks along Medford St.
- Add stop signs and "yield to pedestrians" sings in areas of high traffic.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Intersections between Medford St and Decatur St, Old Landing Way, Monument St, Polk St, Elm St, Terminal St, St. Martin St, Pearl St, Allston St, Sackville St, Belmont St, Chappie St, and Main St
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Bike or Bus

SUMMARY: Shared Spaces, a coalition of advocates from the community of Boston, Boston Center for Independent Living (BCIL), Riders' Transportation Access Group (RTAG), Transportation for Massachusetts (T4MA), WalkMass, Boston Cyclists Union (BCU), and MassBike, organized a site visit to Tremont Street on April 14, 2025 to bring together individuals from the city and provide them with a firsthand understanding of shared spaces, their limitations, and potential conflicts. The visit aimed to promote more informed decision making and facilitate relationships between communities.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Re-install benches at floating bus stop locations, including at Tremont and Worcester St; if there is limited space in the bus stop, add a bench on the wide, newly paved sidewalk
- Improve delineation between the sidewalk and the curb ramp to prevent drivers from parking on the sidewalk
- Ensure that all parking spaces are usable by users with ramps; spacing of barriers should be intentional to facilitate ramp deployment and allow wheelchair users to exit their vehicles reliably
- Level the sloped sidewalk near 778 Tremont St
- Add a fully accessible concrete path on the old section of Tremont St
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Designate areas for dumpster storage and other similar needs
- Ensure there are no obstructions that block the right-of-way of all road users
- Ensure bus stops are compliant with ADA guidelines regarding length and width
- Increase wayfinding signage
- Ensure Accessible Pedestrian Signal (APS) is fully accessible
- Enforce regulations regarding designated accessible parking spots
- Update accessible parking map from City of Boston to reflect accurate information
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Tremont St, Massachusetts Ave, Worcester St, Northhampton St, W Springfield St
THEMES: Accessibility, Bike or Bus, Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted a walk assessment in Brockton on October 21, 2014, as part of MassDOT's Bicycle and Pedestrian Safety Program to improve pedestrian safety and walking conditions. The assessment identified high-priority intersections, infrastructure deficits like faded crosswalks and uneven sidewalks, and broader safety concerns, including 9 pedestrian fatalities in 2014. Recommendations ranged from immediate fixes, such as crosswalk repainting, to long-term studies on raised crosswalk feasibility.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Redesign roads to prioritize multimodal transportation, including wider sidewalks and pedestrian-focused infrastructure.
- Install pedestrian-scale lighting to enhance safety and visibility.
- Develop a comprehensive pedestrian education campaign to encourage compliance with traffic signals.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Extend pedestrian signal crossing times and consider installing pedestrian countdown signals.
- Repair and install ADA-compliant curb ramps and detectable warning strips at intersections.
- Trim roadside signs or adjust their height to improve visibility along sidewalks.
- Add temporary wayfinding signs to guide pedestrians.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: School St, Main St, Pleasant St, Warren Ave, Legion Pkwy, Intersection of Main St/Legion Pkwy,  Intersection of Main St/Pleasant St, & Intersection of Pleasant St/Warren Ave
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Accessibility

SUMMARY: The Downtown Brockton Virtual Walk Audit is part of a statewide initiative examining the links between social infrastructure, walkability, and transit access in five Massachusetts Gateway Cities. Co-hosted by WalkMass and MassINC, with support from the Solomon Foundation, the project gathers resident input through virtual discussions and self-led audits. Its goals are to improve local streets and influence state policy to prioritize investments in Gateway Cities.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Provide more opportunities for individuals to seek short- and long-term shelter in Brockton.
- Shorten driveway widths to limit interruptions to the sidewalk.
- Consider a road diet for Warren Avenue to reduce speeds and make more space for planting street trees and widening the sidewalk.
- Add street lamps to increase visibility after sunset.
- As the Redevelopment Authority continues to sell parcels along this stretch, prioritize land uses that will bring street-level activity and encourage people to spend time in the area. Also prioritize creating opportunities for small, local businesses that want to invest in fostering community and civic engagement to take root in this area.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add wayfinding signage, historical markers, and welcoming banners around City Hall Plaza, while increasing green space, plantings, and seating in existing open areas to encourage people to explore and linger downtown.
- Allow food trucks or other activation of unused parking spaces (such as parklets).
- Design a public awareness campaign about existing health and shelter resources for people who are unhoused that reaches people who need this assistance and spend time downtown.
- Asses downtown parking space usage, while collaborating with local businesses to create short-term pop-ups and repurpose unused parking for people-focused areas like seating or play spaces.
- Conduct a sidewalk inventory and make needed repairs.
- Add shelters and seating at bus stops, along with landscaping and protective buffers at existing open spaces.
- Use placemaking strategies to enhance vacant storefronts, encourage property owners to remove fencing, inventory trash cans to improve collection, and create friendly signage to promote litter-free spaces.
- Work with public health officials and service providers to increase resources and create a public awareness campaign about available support for substance abuse, mental health, and homelessness in downtown Brockton.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: School St, Montello St, Centre St, Legion Pkwy, Warren Ave, L St, & Frederick Douglass Ave
THEMES: Equity , Comfort & Safety, Public Health

SUMMARY: A walk audit in Brockton, conducted on August 16th with the Wildlands Trust Green Team, focused on D.W. Field Park to identify walkability and pedestrian safety challenges. The audit, involving youth from the Brockton area, gathered insights on shared-use roadways and pedestrian trails, with the goal of informing recommendations to improve mobility for all park users.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install a push button APS near D.W. Field Park entrance and redesign entrances with curb extensions for improved pedestrian visibility.
- Analyze and improve wayfinding materials to enhance storytelling and highlight the park's history.
- Use eco-friendly materials for proper drainage on pedestrian paths and ensure safe separation of transportation modes.
- Install gazebos and other shelters throughout the park to improve the user experience and to protect pedestrians in inclement weather.
- Construct permanent restrooms at both ends of the park, add an information hub near the entrance, improve signage, and implement a dog waste management system with additional bins and signage.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install pedestrian signage on Oak Street to increase driver awareness and repaint crosswalks with zebra striping for better visibility.
- Enhance wayfinding signage and install kiosks in key locations to provide visitors with important information.
- Draft a plan for pedestrian-only paths and improve signage for better communication between park transportation modes.
- Install more bike racks at park entrances and explore separating transit modes with bike lanes.
- Fix drainage issues on pedestrian paths and explore ways to improve park usability year-round.
- Improve porta potty conditions with regular cleaning, increase their number, and place them strategically throughout the park.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: D.W. Field East and West Pkwy
THEMES: Bike or Bus, Comfort & Safety, Accessibility

SUMMARY: The Campello neighborhood walk audit was conducted on June 26, 2025, by WalkMassachusetts, local residents, and community partners. It aimed to evaluate pedestrian conditions, identify barriers to walkability, and recommend improvements for the Campello neighborhood in Brockton. The audit was supported by the Underserved Communities Traffic Safety Grant and conducted in partnership with Old Colony Planning Council.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider hiring a dedicated city transportation planner.
- Reconstruct sidewalks to modern standards (wider, continuous).
- Reduce curb radii at intersections, install permanent bus shelters, plant more street trees.
- Signalize hazardous intersections (Nilsson/Main, Main/Forest), and upgrade crossings with accessible pedestrian signals.
- Redesign parking and commercial back entrances for safer access.
- Implement traffic calming (raised crosswalks, curb extensions).
- Continue community engagement and public education on pedestrian safety.
- Pursue comprehensive, permanent infrastructure improvements in line with Brockton’s and OCPC’s safety plans.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint high-visibility crosswalks, upgrade to ADA compliance, add tactile pavers/curb ramps.
- Install trash bins near businesses and bus stops.
- Add benches and temporary shade at major transit stops.
- Enforce sidewalk parking, improve lighting, prune/replace trees, replace missing signage.
- Commission access management studies to reduce driveway conflicts and enhance safety at key intersections.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Main Street, Nilsson Street, Warren Avenue, Florence Street, and Forest Avenue.
THEMES: Equity , Racial Equity , Connectivity, Economic Development
VIEW: Campello Neighborhood Walk Audit Report Brockton 2025
FACILITATOR\/AUTHOR: Iolando Spinola, Brendan Kearney, & Christine Park

SUMMARY: The Montello neighborhood walk auidt was conducted on May 21, 2025, organized by WalkMassachusetts and Old Colony Planning Council with support from the Underserved Communities Traffic Safety Grant. The audit focused on pedestrian safety, accessibility, comfort, and equity—especially for underserved and vulnerable residents. The neighborhood is experiencing transformation, with new zoning and planning efforts aiming for walkable, vibrant mixed-use development.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Full reconstruction of sidewalks and crosswalks, ensuring ADA compliance and logical, continuous pedestrian network.
- Installing permanent RRFBs (flashing beacons) and audible pedestrian signals at high-traffic crossings.
- Traffic calming: curb bumpouts, raised crosswalks, road diets, speed feedback signage, and reduced speed limits (city should consider opting into 25 mph standard).
- Comprehensive wayfinding systems for MBTA, schools, parks, and businesses.
- Permanent amenities: benches, shelters, street trees, upgraded lighting.
- Addressing chronic flooding with engineered drainage solutions.
- Regular maintenance for all pedestrian infrastructure.
- Coordinated efforts between city council, traffic commission, and public works.
- Integrate walkability and equity into all transportation and land use planning.
- Consider hiring a dedicated transportation planner.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Restriping faded crosswalks, relocating them for better connectivity.
- Adding high-visibility crossing markings and temporary curb ramps/tactile surfaces for ADA compliance.
- Repairing malfunctioning pedestrian signals, especially around MBTA station and major intersections.
- Clearing sidewalk obstructions (cars, snow, overgrowth) and ensuring ADA ramps connect logically.
- Temporary improvements: speed feedback signs, benches at bus stops/along routes, temporary wayfinding signs, enhanced lighting, temporary flood mitigation.
- Using “See-Click-Fix” and maintenance reporting tools for rapid hazard response.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Montello MBTA station, Wilmington Street, North Main Street, and Ames Street
THEMES: MBTA, Transit, Climate Change - Heat , Bike or Bus, Schools, Racial Equity , Equity , Policy
VIEW: Montello Neighborhood Walk Audit Report Brockton 2025
FACILITATOR\/AUTHOR: Iolando Spinola, Brendan Kearney, Jonathan Gomez-Pereira, Emma Itri, & Christine Park

SUMMARY: The East Side walk auidt in Brockton was conducted on August 14, 2025 by WalkMassachusetts and Old Colony Planning Council, with support from the Underserved Communities Traffic Safety Grant. The focus was on evaluating walkability, accessibility, and pedestrian equity along Center Street, Galen Street, Crescent Street, and Quincy Street. Participants included residents, local and state officials, public health, environmental justice, and educational stakeholders—all prioritizing safer, more inclusive mobility.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Citywide ADA curb ramp upgrade plan—ensure all ramps meet standards, with tactile and auditory features.
- Hire a dedicated transportation planner or create a city transportation department.
- Adopt road diets on Centre and Crescent, narrowing lanes for calmer traffic and reallocating space for sidewalks, bike lanes, or landscaped buffers.
- Systematically fill gaps in sidewalk networks; improve routes to schools, parks, Massasoit Community College, and transit.
- Add mid-block crossings with refuge islands and/or beacons; expand the street tree program for cooling and comfort.
- Implement consistent, citywide bike lanes separated from traffic.
- Pursue grants to support sidewalk, crossing, and lighting upgrades.
- Expand accessible pedestrian routes from Crescent Street into the plaza and investigate safer drop-off zones.
- Establish annual walkability assessments for ongoing equity.
- Develop infrastructure plans for new developments (sidewalks, shade, benches).
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install truncated domes (tactile warning surfaces) at Centre and Quincy.
- Use barriers or landscaping to clearly separate sidewalks from business parking areas.
- Repave Crescent Street landings for ADA access to the plaza/grocery.
- Install Rapid Flashing Beacon across Crosby Road; install a stop sign at Adams and Centre.
- Upgrade/reposition pedestrian signals at Crescent and Quincy; install new/raised crosswalks, especially near Caffrey Towers.
- Re-time pedestrian signals on Crescent for slower walkers.
- Make all crosswalk lines visible and add new signals near Brockton Hospital.
- Address drop-off/pick-up safety for students at the Crescent Plaza.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Center Street, Galen Street, Crescent Street, and Quincy Street.
THEMES: Age Friendly , Accessibility, Equity , Racial Equity , Economic Development , Climate Change - Heat , Transit, Bike or Bus
VIEW: East Side Walk Audit Report Brockton 2025
FACILITATOR\/AUTHOR: Iolando Spinola, Brendan Kearney, Jonathan Gomez-Pereira, & Christine Park

SUMMARY: This audit, conducted June 26, 2025 by WalkMassachusetts and the Old Colony Planning Council, reviewed pedestrian conditions along West Street, West Elm Street, Moraine Street, Belmont Street, and Torrey Street. It brought together residents, city officials, local advocates, youth leaders, and environmental groups to evaluate accessibility, safety, and walkability for all users, particularly focusing on equity and the lived experiences of families, seniors, people with disabilities, and students.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Develop a citywide ADA curb ramp upgrade plan, ensuring tactile and auditory features.
- Hire a full-time transportation planner or create a city transportation department to coordinate mobility improvements.
- Adopt road diets for Belmont and Torrey, reallocating space for pedestrians and cyclists.
- Fill sidewalk network gaps, prioritizing routes to schools, parks, transit, and residential areas.
- Add mid-block crossings and pedestrian refuge islands, especially along long blocks.
- Systematic expansion of separated bike lanes and consistent citywide pavement markings.
- Expand tree planting on both sides of all priority corridors.
- Launch regular (annual) walkability assessments for ongoing progress.
- Pursue state, federal, and private grants for capital investment in walking infrastructure.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:

SUMMARY: WalkBoston and MassBike conducted an assessment of pedestrian and bicycle infrastructure along Harvard Street in the Town of Brookline on Tuesday, August 9, 2016. The assessment focused on Harvard Street between Longwood Avenue to the south and Shailer Street to the north in the Coolidge Corner area of Brookline, MA with hopes to address the safety and accessibility concerns regarding the region.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Provide continuous separated bike lanes throughout the study area by conducting further analysis on the potential to narrow travel lanes, remove travel lanes, or remove parking.
- Further study feasibility of relocating on-street parking north of Beacon St to Centre St parking lot to provide wider sidewalks and high quality bicycle facilities.
- Provide bicycle facilities on nearby Centre St, Winchester St, and Park St which may provide an alternate route for bicyclists routing around Coolidge Corner.
- Reconstruct curb ramps to meet accessibility standards.
- Shorten crosswalks with curb extensions or pedestrian crossing islands where such treatments would not interfere with current or future bicycle facilities.
- Coordinate intersection improvements with the selected Babcock St alternative.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Conduct a traffic analysis of the Harvard St corridor and surrounding street network for potential mitigation of traffic flow along the corridor.
- Reduce pedestrian tripping hazards by replacing sidewalk panels and further implementing the Town's pervious tree grate program; develop strategies to improve the quality and health of street trees such as installation of permeable pavement.
- Identify citizen or business sponsors to install, program, and maintain parklets in high pedestrian areas.
- Add bicycle left-turn queue boxes where feasible.
- Modify the "WALK YOUR BIKE" signs or rotate the signs to clarify the circumstances in which bicyclists should walk their bikes.
- Install additional bike parking or on-street bike corrals in convenient and visible locations throughout the study area.
- Install pedestrian countdown indications at signalized intersections; extend leading pedestrian intervals.
- Review or reevaluate far-side bus stops to replace existing near bus stop.
- Add 'Don't Block the Box' markings and signs that conform to the latest version of the MUTCD.
- Restrict left turns from Longwood Ave onto Harvard St southbound.
- Install in-street warning signs on the Harvard St and Longwood Ave crosswalks.
- Widen bicycle lane by reducing width of travel lanes and install flexposts.
- Remove warning signs and replace with a bike lane sign.
- Install wayfinding signage on southbound Harvard St north of Beacon St to inform drivers of the need to position for a left turn onto Longwood Ave prior to Beacon St.
- Remove right-turn lane and allocate the space for bicycle facilities for the Beacon St westbound approach.
- Remove or redesign the two existing small islands on the Harvard St/Beacon St intersection.
- Replace the existing crosswalks with high visibility ladder style crosswalks.
- Study providing one stage pedestrian crossings across Beacon St.
- Maximize pedestrian crossing times for all approaches.
- Install bicycle box for the Harvard St southbound approach to Beacon St.
- Evaluate adding contraflow bicycle lane on Green St and potential intersection improvements at Harvard and Green St.
- Modify signal to lagging left turn instead of leading left turns to allow people waiting to cross first.
- Close exit driveway from Centre St parking lot or restrict parking by removing adjacent parking meters, adding NO PARKING pavement markings, and adding NO PARKING signs.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Harvard St, Babcock St, Green St, Beacon St, Longwood Ave
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, Bike or Bus, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Accessibility

SUMMARY: MassBike and WalkMass led a walk and bike assessment in Cambridge on November 5, 2014, as part of MassDOT's program to improve safety in high-crash areas. The assessment aimed to enhance local knowledge, guide safety projects, and promote safer walking and biking.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Distribute space to modes with the largest volumes, similar to Times Square.
- Remove traffic signals and install a roundabout at Cambridge and Hampshire Streets; close off minor streets to simplify traffic patterns.
- Convert Cambridge and Hampshire Streets into one-way streets or prioritize pedestrian and bicycle use on one street.
- Conduct a parking supply and demand study to explore removing parking for improved bike facilities.
- Reduce ambiguous intersection space and separate movements.
- Shrink crosswalk lengths and improve walkability by connecting open spaces.
- Convert the single intersection at Springfield, Cambridge, and Hampshire Streets into two intersections.
- Coordinate signal timing for cars and cyclists across the study area to improve traffic flow.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Close Hampshire Street between Prospect and Cambridge Streets or make it a shared street.
- Prohibit parking during rush hour and use parking spaces as travel lanes for cars or bikes.
- Increase enforcement of parking violations in bike lanes, double parking, jaywalking, and running red lights.
- Evaluate signal timings to ensure bicyclists have adequate clearance time.
- Pilot geometric or temporal street closures on Hampshire and Cambridge Streets for public space use.
- Add dedicated bike-signal heads at Hampshire and Beacon Streets.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Inman Square
THEMES: Economic Development , Connectivity, Comfort & Safety, Bike or Bus

SUMMARY: WalkBoston held a Walk Audit training with the Chelsea Walking Group, which included community members, Health Center staff, and city officials. The training aimed to engage participants in evaluating Chelsea's walking environment and learning how to report needed safety improvements. Participants were introduced to the "See Click Fix" app, which many downloaded for future use.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install a curb extension or bump-out on Broadway at the northwest corner of Bellingham Square to shorten crossing distances and improve pedestrian visibility.
- Narrow curb cut openings on Hawthorne Street between Broadway and Division Street to enhance pedestrian safety, especially during reconstruction projects.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Contact Community Outreach Group (COG) to create a beautification plan for a small commercial and residential area in Chelsea.
- Install a crosswalk at the intersection of Shurtleff/Central on the east crossing of Central.
- Repair broken sidewalks on Hawthorne Street, Shawmut Street, and other noted locations.
- Remove or repair tree grates on Hawthorne Street to eliminate tripping hazards and improve wheelchair accessibility.
- Relocate the Bellingham Square bus stop from the narrow sidewalk on Broadway to north Broadway.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Bellingham St, Broadway, Central Ave,  Shawmut St, & Hawthorne St
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Public Health, Accessibility, Connectivity, Age Friendly

SUMMARY: On May 31, 2017, WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment in the Sector 4 area of downtown Chelsea, with support from the Massachusetts Department of Public Health’s Mass in Motion program. Chelsea is undergoing a wave of urban revitalization, yet long-standing community concerns about crime and public safety persist, and many poorly designed intersections create dangerous conditions for people walking, biking, taking transit, and driving. The goals of the walk assessment were to examine these issues related to public and traffic safety and to recommend improvements to the local built environment that create safer walking conditions for everyone.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Create a comprehensive local pilot focused on street lighting, neighborhood beautification, and traffic calming.
- Consider fining landlords who do not take adequate measures to keep their properties clean.
- Plant street trees and fill empty tree pits with mulch or permeable pavers to create a more even and attractive sidewalk environment while providing a green canopy cover that also protects against the strong urban heat island effects in Chelsea.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Provide additional trash receptacles in places with a lot of litter to help beautify the neighborhood and improve perceptions of safety by conveying that the community cares for the area.
- Use paint, plastic flex posts and/or planters to take away excess roadway space from motor vehicles, reduce speeding and pedestrian crossing distances, and provide pedestrian refuge islands.
- Add lane markings and fog lines on the pavement to more clearly delineate vehicular movements and narrow travel lanes.
- Restripe and add crosswalks with highly visible ladder designs and install in-street pedestrian crossing signs at crosswalks.
- Add and retime WALK signals to provide sufficient pedestrian crossing time.
- Restrict parking next to crosswalks to improve driver and pedestrian sightlines.
- Upgrade dim lights to brighter LEDs where possible and trim street trees to ensure they do not obstruct lights; all lighting should be pedestrian-scaled to adequately illuminate sidewalks as well as streets.
- Add a highly visible crosswalk at the bus stop at the Everett Ave/Chestnut St/Third St intersection; the current median island should be enhanced to better accommodate pedestrians.
- Add signage, pavement markings, and plastic flex posts and/or planters to discourage and block illegal U-turns.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Park Square, Park St, Pearl St, Congress Ave, Cross St, Fay Square, Washington St, Sixth St, Chestnut St, Fourth St, Route 1, Everett Ave, Third St
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Connectivity

SUMMARY: On September 7, 2017, WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment in the Park Square area of downtown Chelsea, with support from the Massachusetts Executive Office of Public Safety and Security (EOPSS). The goal of the walk assessment was to recommend  improvements to the local built environment that improve pedestrian safety.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Improve visibility at the crosswalk across Hawthorne St by adding curb extensions and physically restricting parking next to the crosswalk, using paint, plastic flex posts, and "No Parking" signage.
- Turn the triangular white painted area at Pearl and 4th St as well as the triangular cobblestone area at Park Square and Congress Ave into a pedestrian refuge island with plastic flex posts and planters to protect people crossing the street and to further calm and delineate the movements of turning vehicles.
- Create curb extensions with paint and plastic flex posts to narrow vehicular turning radii, thus calming traffic, improving driver/pedestrian sightlines, and reducing pedestrian crossing distances.
- Add STOP signs facing east and west on Central Ave at Shurtleff St to replace the non-operational signals there (these signals can potentially be relocated to other locations in Chelsea that may require signalization).
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Narrow the travel lane on Hawthorne St by painting a bike lane, thus turning Hawthorne St into a truly multimodal transportation corridor with slower vehicular traffic.
- Add signage telling drivers turning left from Hawthorne St onto Pearl/4th St to yield to pedestrians and informing pedestrians crossing Pearl St to look out for turning traffic.
- Relocate the crosswalks across the Park St and Hawthorne St approaches closer to the intersection to improve sightlines for drivers and pedestrians and to reduce the incidence of drivers rolling through/blocking the crosswalks.
- Add in-street pedestrian crossing signs at crosswalks to calm traffic.
- Add travel lane markings to clearly delineate vehicular movements approaching and continuing through the Park/Hawthorne/Central intersection.
- Add plastic flex posts to the existing white painted area on the northwest side of the Park/Hawthorne/Central intersection to physically restrict parking there.
- Add a new crosswalk across Park Square at Cross St.
- Add signage at the eastern and western edges of Park Square telling turning drivers to yield to pedestrians and informing pedestrians to look out for turning traffic.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Park Square, Park St, Central Ave, Hawthorne St, Cross St, Congress Ave, Pearl St, 4th St
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: The Hilltowns CDC, Healthy Hampshire, and WalkMass are leading a 5-year grant project to enhance age-friendly walkability in Hilltowns Town Centers, including Chesterfield, through walk audits and infrastructure planning. Chesterfield residents prioritize safer walking routes, including sidewalks along Main Road near the CDC offices and Davenport Childcare Center, as well as social spaces like Russell Memorial Park and the Chesterfield General Store & Cafe. Suggestions include adding benches, enhancing recreational opportunities for older adults, and improving safety features for key walking routes to foster community cohesion.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Update other park elements, such as the swing set and play structures, and include a fall safe surface to mitigate the impact of any falls. An adaptive swing set and other play structures would also increase the accessibility of the park.
- Consider planting more trees to increase shade.
- Improve walking connection from the Town Center to the Chesterfield General Store and Bagg Road intersection
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Reduce traffic speeds on Main Road through the Town Center by reducing lane widths, considering installing a 4-way stop at the South Street/N Road/Main Road intersection, and continuing the use of speed feedback signs on Route 143.
- Improve safety and visibility of the pedestrian crossing in front of the Library by repainting crosswalks with a continental stripe pattern and installing a pedestrian-activated Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacon (RRFB).
- Add more benches  to Russell Memorial Park to promote community gathering for people of all ages and abilities.
- Study different options for improving pedestrian access to the Hilltown CDC and Child Care Center.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Main Rd., Intersection of Main Rd. & South St., & Russel Memorial Park
THEMES: Age Friendly, Connectivity, Comfort

SUMMARY: The Hilltown CDC, Healthy Hampshire, and WalkMass are collaborating on a 5-year grant project to improve age-friendly walkability in Hilltown Village Centers, including Cummington. The initiative involves walk audits to identify infrastructure improvements and policy changes that make walking safer and more enjoyable for all ages. Cummington's efforts face challenges like fast traffic on Route 9 and incomplete sidewalks, but the community remains committed to enhancing pedestrian safety and accessibility to key local attractions.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- TIghten the curb radii by reducing width of the intersection by redesigning the street with narrower travel lanes and less asphalt.
- Evaluate and explore options to improve pedestrian access and safety along and across Route 9 to reach the Fairgrounds, the Creamery, and the Library by engage with MassDOT District 1 traffic engineers to determine options for
improving pedestrian safety along Route 9.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Complete the pedestrian crossing(s) and curb cuts at the Church/Community House.
- Tighten the curb radii by painting curb lines that narrow the travel lanes to 10’ wide or painting curb bump outs and a crosswalk. 
- Explore options for making walking safer on Main Street between the intersection of Plainfield Road and Route 9 by Determining the legal right-of-way dimensions along this stretch of road, considering posting additional advisory signage indicating pedestrians are sharing the roadway, considering using paint to alert drivers that people are walking/rolling along this stretch, and evaluating traffic patterns.

SUMMARY: The Niagara Senior Center walk audit, conducted by WalkMass in partnership with Fall River's Mass in Motion program, focused on improving walkability in the Niagara/Maplewood neighborhood. Around 20 senior residents participated in the event, which included a presentation on walkability followed by an on-street audit of nearby routes. Participants identified areas for improvement, such as safety enhancements and sidewalk repairs, with the goal of making the neighborhood more accessible and pleasant for walking.

- Construct permanent bulb-outs at the mid block crossing.
- Investigate the need for a raised crossing (speed table) and/or pedestrian activated flashing warning lights (HAWK signal)

- Install curb ramps serving the crosswalk.
- Paint “bulb-outs” on the pavement, with no parking posted 20’ back from the crossing on either side.
- Provide an “in-street pedestrian crossing sign on the street center line.

The purpose of the walk assessment was to foster an awareness of the infrastructure elements which contribute to the walking environment, evaluate the safety and quality of the walking environment along the route, and recommend infrastructure improvements.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install pedestrian push button signal at intersections to provide protected crossing across Bedford St
- Consider changing the signal timing at intersections so that pedestrians can cross more quickly and efficiently; evaluate the vehicle volumes to see if concurrent phasing with a leading pedestrian indicator (LPI) is possible
- Upgrade the pedestrian signal heads to a countdown signal at the Robeson/13th St intersection
- Consider traffic calming measures to slow traffic on Robeson St (e.g. raised speed tables, curb bump-outs); paint edge (fog) lines along Robeson to narrow travel lanes
- Install and replace existing curb ramps with ADA-compliant ramps and detectable warning strips
- Evaluate location of crosswalks; assuming utility poles and fire hydrants cannot be moved, crosswalks may need to move slightly outside pedestrian desire lines to meet ADA requirements
- Upgrade crosswalk pavement markings to 'piano keys', ladder, or continental design

- Evaluate the location of mid-block crosswalks for adequate sight lines on Robeson St Corridor
- Install pedestrian crosswalk and advanced crosswalk signage at mid-block crossings
- Replace non-compliant STOP signs with proper STOP signs
- Replace peeling and damaged detectable warning strips with more permanent solutions
- Enforce ordinance to keep sidewalks clear and trim vegetation along sidewalks

SUMMARY: On May 10, 2017, WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment in the vicinity of the William S. Greene Elementary School in Fall River, in partnership with the Fall River Mass in Motion program and the Massachusetts Department of Transportation’s (MassDOT) Safe Routes to School (SRTS) program. The goals of the walk assessment were to examine pedestrian safety issues that may preclude children from walking to the Greene School and to recommend improvements to the local built environment that enable safer walking.

- Implement a clearly marked pedestrian refugre island at Brayton Ave to create a safe waiting area in the middle of the street
- Install a traffic light with WALK signals or a pedestrian-activated HAWK (High-Intensity-Activated crossWalK) beacon to stop traffic at the crosswalk across Brayton Ave
- Reduce the posted speed limit on Brayton Ave form 30 miles per hour to 25 miles per hour in conjunction with a broader citywide approach to lowering speed limits
- Extend the school zone and lower the speed limit on Warren St to 20 miles per hour

- Paint fog lines at the edge of parking lanes to narrow travel lanes and calm traffic
- Implement high-visibility signage including in-street pedestrian crossing signs to draw driver attention to the crosswalk
- Upgrade crosswalks and install traffic calming measures along Warren St

THEMES: Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted an Age-Friendly Walking audit in downtown Fall River near the South Main Senior Center through the Massachusetts Department of Public Health's Mass in Motion Program. This initiative responded to a 2019 MassDOT report highlighting Fall River as one of four Massachusetts communities with disproportionately high pedestrian crash rates among older adults, with 141 crashes involving individuals aged 55+ between 2016 and 2020.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Improve the safety of midblock crosswalks with enhancements such as daylighting, adding bump outs to narrow the street and thus slow traffic and shorten crossing distances, or raised crosswalks.
- Plan to upgrade all pedestrian traffic signals to ensure that they are fully accessible pedestrian signals with a countdown for WALK times.
- Improve the accessibility of the walking environment by repairing and replacing crumbling curb ramps. 
- Inventory the sidewalks of this corridor and replace sections that are in disrepair to provide smoother, more level walking surfaces. Replace sections of mixed materials with concrete.
- Consider speed reduction strategies for South Main Street to improve the safety and comfort of the walking environment.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Enhance the visibility of crosswalks on South Main Street with signage and paint. 
- Extend the WALK signal length at key intersections in the downtown corridor to give pedestrians
more time to safely cross the street.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: South  Main St from Pocasset St. Intersection to Spring St. Intersection
THEMES: Age Friendly , "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: The City of Fitchburg is developing a broader Complete Streets prioritization plan, and the non-profit Montachusett Opportunity Council (MOC), which administers a local Mass in Motion program to promote active transportation options, invited WalkBoston to conduct a walk assessment of the Main Street area to help guide this effort.The assessment took place on October 25, 2016 and was designed to further examine local pedestrian infrastructure conditions to recomment potential improvements.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Upgrade crosswalks to include ladder design, high-visibility signage, and accessible curb ramps.
- Add bumpouts/curb extensions at key crossings and intersections to reduce crossing distances, slow turning traffic, and enhance visibility between people walking and driving.
- Provide additional bike lanes beyond the short section of Main St where they have been painted.
- Explore opportunities to remove on-street parking and reclaim more roadway space for pedestrian/bike uses and public realm improvements at the Main St commercial core (e.g. parklets).
- Reduce the number off eastbound travel lanes to calm traffic on Boulder Drive; paint fog lines on the road to narrow travel lanes as a near-term traffic calming measure (before reducing the overall number of travel lanes).
- Add bike lanes on Boulder Drive as part of roadway reconfiguration.
- Enhance pedestrian connections between Boulder Drive and Fitchburg Riverfront Park.
- Consider adding a flashing beacon or traffic signal at the Main/Cushing/Blossom St intersection to calm traffic.
- Upgrade WALK signals to be automatic, concurrent with traffic, provide pedestrian head starts, and allow sufficient time for people to cross the street.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add wayfinding signage to create a sense of connectivity between key destinations downtown and elsewhere.
- Provide regular bus or shuttle service between downtown and the Fitchburg State University campus.
- Retain the single lane layout beyond the one-year pilot at the Main St commercial core and use additional roadway space for bike lanes and/or parklets (sidewalk extensions that provide more space and ammenities for people using the street.
- Add plastic flex posts to the yellow-painted median on Main St to prevent wide left turns at high speeds.
- Add protected pedestrian refuge islands in the crosswalks to the Intermodal Transit Center using paint and plastic flex posts.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Main St, Boulder Dr, Cushing St, Blossom St, North St
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, Bike or Bus, Youth, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: The Fitchburg Intermodal Center Virtual Walk Audit is part of a statewide project focused on improving social infrastructure, neighborhood walkability, and transit access in five Gateway Cities in Massachusetts. It incorporates neighborhood data and resident input through virtual discussions and self-led audits. The project aims to achieve safer, more enjoyable streets at the local level and influence state policies and budget priorities for Gateway Cities. Co-hosted by WalkMass and MassINC, it is supported by the Solomon Foundation.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install bike lanes, especially on North St and Main St, to increase safety for bicyclists and help calm traffic, benefitting all users of the street.
- Consider adding rectangular rapid flash beacons (RRFBs) at crosswalks, conforming to MUTCD guidelines.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Form a bike/ped committee for Fitchburg to keep advancing this important work. WalkMass can provide guidance on how to create and set priorities for the group through the Mass in Motion technical assistance program, in partnership with Tricia Pistone.
- Add benches along North St and Main St where space permits.
- Add trash receptacles along North St, Main St and Lunenburg St and in the parks along these streets.
- Repaint crosswalks with ladder markings.

SUMMARY: On Thursday, September 13, 2018, WalkBoston conducted a walk audit at Dennison Crossing in Framingham as part of the Executive Office of Public Safety and Security’s (EOPSS) Pedestrian Safety Planning Initiative for High-Fatality Communities. WalkBoston is working in partnership with EOPSS to address walking safety concerns in Massachusetts communities with high pedestrian crash rates, one of which happens to be Framingham, and the goal is to reduce pedestrian fatalities and serious injuries in the Commonwealth. Dennison Crossing was a particular area of concern because it is a vehicle-dominated landscape with high traffic volumes moving at relatively high speeds.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install accessible pedestrian signals (including countdown clocks) at all traffic signal locations.
- Make comprehensive accessibility improvements to sidewalks in the Dennison Crossing residential districts.
- Link the multi-use path near the MetroWest Regional Transit Authority (MWRTA) transit center to others to form a network of safe walking and biking connections through downtown Framingham.
- Consider the multi-use pathway as an opportunity to display public art to improve the aesthetics of the industrial settings and fence-line. A relevant example is the "May This Never End" art piece formerly on the Rose Kennedy Greenway and now in Allston, MA.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Complete a comprehensive assessment of actual signal cycle lengths at each intersection in Dennison Crossing to verify the times collected during the walk audit.
- Reprogram traffic signals to minimize pedestrian wait times (less than 90 seconds). Consider an automatic walk signal if concurrent phasing is employed.
- Consider typical walker destinations and program signals so that people can cross to their destination in a single WALK cycle.
- Evaluate the location and safety of crosswalks across Bishop Street at both the Clinton and Howard intersections to better serve the vulnerable populations using this busy corridor.
- Determine whether there are low cost, quick fixes to improving sidewalk accessibility (e.g., paving details to accommodate mature trees, replacement of individual concrete panels rather than replacing the entire length of sidewalk).
- Identify funding stream to install accessible sidewalks where they are missing throughout Dennison Crossing.
- Trim trees along south side of Howard Street.
- Improve wayfinding signs to better identify the trail as a public, safe, enjoyable alternative to walking along Blandin Avenue and Waverly Street
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Dennison Crossing, Concord St, Clinton St, Bishop St, Blandin Ave, Waverly St, Howard St, Kendall St
THEMES: Connectivity, Comfort & Safety, Accessibility

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted a 1.8-mile walk audit near Davis Thayer Elementary and Oak Street Elementary Schools in Franklin, Massachusetts, to assess walking conditions in the area. Organized by the Hockomock YMCA with funding from the MetroWest Community Health Foundation, the audit aimed to evaluate the walkability of public streets around the schools. Participants included staff from WalkMass, Hockomock YMCA, and faculty members from both schools.

- Convert all streets to two-way and re-engineer the Emmons and West Central intersection into either a more traditional signalized 4-way intersection or a roundabout.
- Rebuild a wider sidewalk with solid curbs from Church Street to Maple Street.
- Replace the damaged pedestrian signal and button, and update the signal timing.
- Add button-activated pedestrian crossing signals at the Emmons and West Central intersection.
- Replace the damaged concrete slab and extend the sidewalk to Maple Street with concrete for durability and better walking surfaces.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Repair or replace the broken sections of sidewalk.
- Add crosswalks on West Central on the eastern and western edges of the intersection and north of the intersection on Emmons.
- Replace the YIELD sign at Emmons and West Central with a STOP sign.
- Create curb ramps by building ramps with asphalt to provide access from the street to the sidewalk.
- Fill in the hole with asphalt and extend the sidewalk using asphalt from its terminus to Maple Street.
- Update the signal timing on the walk button that currently works.
- Remove the granite curb at the corners and build ADA-compliant access ramps.

THEMES: Accessibility, Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted a walk audit near Helen Keller Elementary and Annie Sullivan Middle Schools in Franklin, Massachusetts, focusing on the pedestrian route between the school and Dacey Field, a remote drop-off location. Organized by the Hockomock YMCA with funding from the MetroWest Community Health Foundation, the audit involved WalkMass staff, YMCA staff, and a school grandparent.

- Re-engineer the Winterberry Drive intersection with narrower turning radii.

- Add a crosswalk and “Children Crossing” signage at the Winterberry Drive intersection, and visually narrow the road by painting white lines a few feet in from each curb.
- Re-paint white fog lines to slow traffic by narrowing travel lanes.
- Work with residents to find alternative mailbox mounting techniques to keep sidewalks clear.
- Expand the sidewalk with asphalt around utility poles to improve pedestrian access.

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit workshop in the Montachusett Region in partnership with the Montachusett Public Health Network's Healthy Weight Initiative. The workshop covered the basics of pedestrian infrastructure, included an on-street walk audit in Gardner to evaluate the walking environment, and provided a discussion on findings and the audit process. Participants were encouraged to apply the skills learned to conduct similar workshops in their own communities.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Improve sidewalks and streetscape elements on Pleasant Street south of City Hall.
- Install and/or repair curbs, reinforce, and resurface sidewalks on Baker Street between Pleasant Street and Nichols Street.
- Remove parking lane and widen sidewalks on Baker Street beyond Nichols Street.
- Convert the parking lot at the intersection of Parker Street and City Hall Avenue into a public plaza space.
- Paint bike lanes on both sides of Waterford Street to provide bike facilities and calm vehicular traffic.
- Narrow driveway widths and tighten curb radii in the downtown area of Parker Street.
- Maintain wide street rights-of-way (ROWs) for snow storage while using paint to better delineate vehicular lanes, bike lanes, and parking stalls.

- Paint center lines and fog lines on Baker Street.
- Widen crosswalks and enhance or eliminate the crosswalk at Harvard Street.
- Install pedestrian crossing signs at mid-block crossings on Parker Street.
- Maintain brick crosswalks and pavement markings.

SUMMARY: The “Reimagining Railroad Avenue” study by MAPC and Gloucester focuses on improving pedestrian safety and quality in the area, particularly for senior citizens. Using “Healthy Aging through Community Design” funds, city officials, WalkBoston, and residents collaborated to identify challenges through community meetings and a walk audit. The audit highlighted hazardous conditions seniors face daily when accessing essential destinations like food, pharmacies, and transit.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Replace and repair sidewalks to create accessible routes connecting senior housing complexes to the Railroad Avenue area.
- Implement raised crosswalks and curb extensions to slow down vehicular traffic.
- Revise zoning ordinances and parking requirements to mitigate the impact of increased parking demand.
- Conduct a parking management study to explore shared parking districts and strategies to allow for wider sidewalks or bike lanes.
- Collaborate with stakeholders to develop long-term snow removal programs targeting key pedestrian routes.
- Use paint to test new traffic patterns at critical intersections.
- Develop a strategy to remove unnecessary on-street parking, enabling the addition of wider sidewalks, bike lanes, and other active street facilities.-
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Monitor speeds and increase police enforcement if speeding is prevalent.
- Increase police enforcement and issue tickets to violators.
- Upgrade all crosswalks to ladder-style markings.
- Use paint to define pedestrian zones in areas with wide driveways and undefined parking lots.
- Reevaluate pedestrian-activated traffic beacons to ensure adequate crossing time for seniors.
- Review the Department of Public Works snow removal procedures.
- Enforce the City Snow Removal Ordinance and enhance snow removal programs for those unable to clear snow themselves.

Washington St, Prospect
St, School St, Smith St, & Railroad Ave

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit with Goshen volunteer staff and residents along Route 9 and East St in response to new senior residences being constructed around the Goshen village center. Hilltown Community Development Corporation (CDC) responded to a Healthy Hampshire Request for Proposals to fund design projects to create more walkable town centers due to these new residences and out of a desire to connect the town's assets with a safe walking route.

- Discuss enhanced pavement markings with MassDOT (e.g. ladder crosswalk design).
- Ensure zoning and planning decisions concenctrate density in village center zone to promote walkability.
- Design and construct an extension of the sidewalk along Route 9 with MassDOT District office.
- Install sidewalk along East St leading to Tilton Farm and the Recycling Center.
- Install wayfinding signage along walking loops between regional open space assets and the Goshen village center.
- Pass a Complete Streets Policy.
- Apply for technical assistance funding for a Complete Streets Prioritization Plan.

- Reach out to other towns in Hampshire County to learn about their experiences implementing traffic calming measures on state-owned roads.
- Install an in-street pedestrian crossing sign and place in crosswalk on Route 9.
- Request advance crosswalk signage along Route 9 on the north side of the crosswalk (currently only implemented on south side).
- Incorporate benches, trees, and public spaces in the new housing development site design.
- Rethink or redesign parking lot, tennis court, and existing park space to better serve the active and passive recreation needs of Goshen residents.
- Determine width of East St right-of-way and evaluate the possibility of delineating pedestrian lane markings (install pedestrian lane if applicable).

SUMMARY: The City of Haverhill is participating in MassDOT’s program to enhance bicycle and pedestrian safety. As part of this initiative, WalkBoston conducted walk assessments with three primary goals: raising awareness of the infrastructure that impacts the walking environment, evaluating the safety and quality of the walking routes, and recommending infrastructure improvements. The City identified several high-priority intersections that pose safety risks to pedestrians and cyclists. With input from the Merrimack Valley Planning Commission, City officials, and the Haverhill Police Department, a walking route was established that focuses on key intersections in the Downtown and Acre neighborhoods.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install and upgrade ADA-compliant curb ramps where needed.
- Evaluate northwest intersection turning radii to accommodate truck traffic and prevent sidewalk driving.
- Consider updating traffic signal design to provide extra gathering space.
- Change signal timing to reduce pedestrian wait times and explore concurrent phasing with LPI.
- Study relocating crosswalk to improve compliance and reduce motorist obstruction.
- Install curb extensions (bump-outs) to improve visibility and shorten crossing distance.
- Explore redesigning median as pedestrian refuge with protection on both sides of the crosswalk.
- Consider installing a pedestrian refuge island median on Washington Street to prevent illegal U-turns and improve safety.
- Evaluate curb extensions to shorten crossing and enhance pedestrian visibility.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Relocate No RTOR signs next to traffic signal heads.
- Repaint stop line on southbound White Street.
- Upgrade pedestrian signal heads to countdown signals.
- Review crosswalks on Winter Street near Locust Street; consider curb extensions or raised intersection.
- Remove parking within 20’ of crosswalk on Winter Street and add signage for pedestrian visibility.
- Paint edge lines/parking stalls to define lanes and slow traffic.
- Repair sidewalks on Locust Street between Winter and Walnut Streets.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Winter St. & Washington Square
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: The Downtown Haverhill Virtual Walk Audit, part of a statewide project by WalkMass and MassINC, explored connections between walkability, transit access, and social infrastructure in Gateway Cities. Haverhill residents participated in online workshops, self-led or guided walk audits, and focus groups, documenting observations to identify areas for improvement. The findings were synthesized into recommendations to enhance walkability and guide local and state investments in safer, more enjoyable streets.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- As new developments are proposed downtown, require publicly accessible green space where possible.
- Improve crosswalk safety with enhanced visibility features and consider adding RRFBs or bump outs at midblock crossings.
- Add lampposts and other lighting at regular intervals along main streets as well as side streets to create a continuously well lit walking path. Ensure that lighting is well maintained and that lightbulbs are replaced when needed.
- Complete the boardwalk as planned.
-For crosswalks where pedestrian visibility is low, add bumpouts, which reduce crossing lengths and make it easier for pedestrians and drivers to see each other coming.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Work with local arts groups to host downtown events and partner with the Boys and Girls Club to engage youth in creating nearby youth-friendly spaces.
- Maintain upkeep of landscaping in existing green spaces and add recreational equipment and dog-friendly areas where space permits.
-  Focus on cleaning and maintaining ladder streets while enhancing streetscapes to create safer, more inviting walking routes downtown
- Add more trash receptacles, increase collection frequency, and conduct regular cleanups.
- Improve crosswalk visibility with in-street signage, reevaluate and extend crossing times, and reduce crossing distances with curb extensions.
- Conduct a sidewalk inventory to identify and prioritize repairs and ensure ongoing maintenance.
- Enhance downtown with murals, art installations, placemaking in vacant storefronts, and add seating, landscaping, and shade to create inviting spaces for pedestrians.
- Add trees, seating, trash bins, and wayfinding signage to enhance comfort and orientation along the route.
- Maintain trash, trim vegetation, and ensure clear sidewalks with more bins and regular upkeep.
- Narrow driving lanes, adjust curb radii to slow speeds, and improve pedestrian visibility, with long-term plans to make these changes permanent.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED:
Section 1: Intersection of Washington Ave and Washington St, West St, & Bailey St

Section 2: Intersection of Bailey Blvd and Emerson St, Winter St, Essex St, & Moulton Way
THEMES: Youth, Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY:
Volunteers and staff members in the Town of Huntington responded to a Healthy Hampshire
Request for Proposal for walkability project funding. The focus of Huntington’s proposal was the planning
and construction of a “River Walk” along the Westfield River to better connect residents and visitors with
the natural assets in the region. Healthy Hampshire reached out to WalkBoston to lead a walk audit with the town staff and residents.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Discuss tightening of curb radii on the southeast corner and narrowing travel lanes at the intersection of Routes 112 and Route 20 just west of the bridge with MassDOT District Office.
- Consider adopting a section of Route 20 and possibly Route 112 to give the town decision-making authority to implement traffic calming measures.
- Acquire funding for crosswalk installations on town-owned and MassDOT roads.
- Install missing sidewalks along Basket St,, Old Chester Rd, and E Main St between Mill St loop road 
- Build missing trail links on the town-owned land walking loop 
- Develop wayfinding signage programs for both walking loops; use trailblazers to list walking times to destinations 
- Include the trolley line easement into regional trail planning initiatives 
- Pass a Complete Streets Policy 
- Apply for technical assistance funding for a Complete Streets Prioritization Plan
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Continue to discuss traffic calming strategies permissible on MassDOT roads with MassDOT District 1 staff; potential for additional in-street pedestrian signs in the crosswalks on Route 112.
- Request MUTCD-approved signs pedestrian awareness signs be placed along Route 20 as drivers approach the town center.
- Reach out to other towns in Hampshire County, such as Williamsburg, Lee and Northampton, to learn more about their experiences implementing traffic calming measures on state-owned roads.
- Consider installing accessible crosswalks with curb ramps; begin conversations with MassDOT to understand feasibility, schedule, and potential funding streams.
- Adopt a town-wide crosswalk standard (ladder or continental); MassDOT may be more likely to upgrade crosswalk designs on state-owned roads if the community has a crosswalk standard.
- Evaluate feasibility of walking loop on town-owned land south of E Main St.
- Publicize walking loops on town website and other platforms to promote their use.
- Begin conversations with MassDOT and the town on prioritizing sidewalk improvements along Route 112, Basket St, and Old Chester Rd.
