SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted a walk audit along Route 132 in Hyannis as part of the EOPSS Pedestrian Safety Planning Initiative, addressing high pedestrian crash rates in Barnstable, which saw 3 fatalities and 122 injuries from 2012-2017. The audit focused on Route 132 between Independence Drive and Nightingale Lane, a high-crash corridor near the Cape Cod Mall and Capetown Plaza. The Town of Barnstable aims to improve pedestrian safety through design changes and is exploring a more walkable, mixed-use redevelopment of Capetown Plaza to enhance accessibility and reduce crashes.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Redesign Route 132 using a complete streets approach with narrower lanes, planted medians, and wide sidewalks or multi-use paths to serve all modes of transportation.
- Study and implement additional signalized pedestrian crossings across Route 132 to improve accessibility to services on both sides of the road.
- Develop connected service roads to enhance internal vehicular and pedestrian circulation along Route 132.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Upgrade sidewalks and curb ramps on the southern side of Route 132 between Independence Drive and Hinckley Road, and evaluate the feasibility of adding sidewalks to the northern side.
- Improve pedestrian crossings at the Cape Cod Mall/Capetown Plaza intersection by enhancing visibility, ensuring ADA compliance, recalibrating signal timing for adequate WALK time, and adding fully functional pedestrian signals.
- Restrict right turns on red at the Cape Cod Mall/Capetown Plaza entry roads to enhance pedestrian safety.
- Install wayfinding signage and designated walking areas to promote pedestrian circulation between adjacent properties.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Route 132 (Iyannough Road)
THEMES: Connectivity, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Economic Development

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walkability workshop on July 28, 2016, funded by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health Mass in Motion program. The workshop discussed the principles of walkable communities and summarized pedestrian infrastructure improvements that increase safety and improve the quality of the wlaking environment. Afterwards, a walk assessment was conducted with the goal of evaluating walking conditions in the Lenox town center, identifying a walking route that connects senior housing to the town center, and considering opportunities for wayfinding signs that highlight walking times to local destinations
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Tighten curb radii at intersections; install curb ramps, crosswalks, and roadside crosswalk signs to make crossing more visible where needed.
- Rethink location of angled parking in front of the Curtis House; redesign to accommodate marked crosswalk between Adams Community Bank and the Curtis House; could include curb bump-out or complete curb realignment to mirror curve and convert to parallel parking, or remove parking entirely to maximize pedestrian visibility.
- Install curb bump-outs at locations where painted lines do not deter parking.
- Consider establishing a safety zone throughout the designated historic district in the town center.
- Establish town-wide guidance on the use of flush curbs to provide developers, designers, and transportation engineers with information on where flush curbs are appropriate.
- Redesign and replace flush curbs with straight curbs in conflict locations.
- Explore other options for slowing fast-moving traffic on Route 7A including narrow lanes.
- Establish sidewalk prioritization plan and annual sidewalk replacement/repair budget to systematically replace aging sidewalks leading to town center.
- Identify locations where sidewalks do not currently exist where there is demand or desire for sidewalks to be built; a town-wide pedestrian plan could identify corridors leading from the town center to trail heads, schools, parks, and other local destinations.
- Study the possibility of reconstructing the intersection of Housatonic St, Ore Bed Rd, and Old Center St with the goal of improving safety.
- Develop an ADA compliance plan for the Town of Lenox that prioritizes areas with the highests volumes of pedestrians.
- Secure funding for ADA compliance projects in the Town of Lenox (e.g. MassDOT Complete Streets funding program and Safe Routes to School Infrastructure program).
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Implement crosswalks and install accessible ramps and sidewalk connections between the municipal parking lots on the east side of Old Stockbridge connecting to the sidewalk on the west side just south of the residential driveway.
- Relocate and/or close the municipal and private residence driveways on Old Stockbridge just south of the West St intersection to make room for a marked crosswalk and accessible ramp.
- Install roadside crosswalk signs to make the crossing more visible.
- Review location of stop sign and stop line where Old Stockbridge meets West St.
- Move existing crosswalk sign at the Walker/West/Main/Old Stockbridge intersection closer to the edge of the road and consider installing advance crosswalk signs.
- Remove parking space striping from the two mid-block crosswalks on Walker St between Church St and Main St intersection and the three mid-block crosswalks on Main St between West St and Cliffwood St.
- Install no parking signs near crosswalks and at intersections.
- Paint diagonal white lines in no parking zones adjacent to crosswalks and intersections.
- Work with the Lenox Police Department to enforce no parking ordinances.
- Establish town crosswalk design standards that include guidelines for raised crossings, raised intersections, mid-block crossings, and crossings at intersections.
- Install temporary curbing along eastern edge of Church St flush curb to differentiate sidewalk from travel way in fron tof children's clothing and toy store.
- Consider temporary curbing at the Franklin St/Main St intersection to delineate sidewalk.
- Paint a ladder crosswalk across Main St at the Main/Franklin intersection.
- Identify priority sidewalks leading to the town center in need of repair/replacement.
- Coordinate with the Department of Public Works resurfacing/reconstruction programs.
- Evaluate feasibility and safety implications of installing a crosswalk between Ore Bed Park and Old Center St.
- Consider installing a sidewalk, pedestrian warning signs, and/or pavement markings to bring awareness that people may be walking.
- Advise the dental office to move their sign so that it does not encroach upon the sidewalk.
- Determine if high priority locations are already on the Department of Public Works schedule for road reconstruction/repaving and ensure that ADA improvements are included in the projects.
- Consider looking for resources to conduct a pilot wayfinding program; identify destinations to include in the program
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Walker St, Route 183, Route 7A, Old Stockbridge Rd, West St, Sunset Ave, Franklin st, Church St, Housatonic St
THEMES: Age Friendly , Connectivity, Rural Communities, Accessibility, Schools, Policy

SUMMARY: The Town of Lenox reached out to WalkBoston to conduct a walk audit in Lenox Dale to assess the safety and quality of the pedestrian environment in the village as well as to identify opportunities to connect the regional open space and historical assests in the Lenox area with walking paths or routes. Lenox is participating in the Massachusetts Department of Transportation (MassDOT) Complete Streets Funding Program to secure funds for bicycle and pedestrian infrastructure projects in town. Lenox has completed the first two steps to receive funding by passing a Complete Streets policy and submitting a Complete Streets Prioritization Plan. WalkBoston completed a walk audit in Lenox Center in the summer of 2016. Many of the infrastructure recommendations made in that audit were included in the Prioritization Plan. The Town of Lenox staff wanted to give Lenox Dale residents the same opportunity to participate in a walk audit to identify needed  infrastructure improvements in the Dale.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Prioritize residential roadways in the Dale in need of additional pedestrian infrastructure such as sidewalks or pavement markings.
- Replace Elm St sidewalk to meet accessibility standards considering width, curb ramps, and detectable warning panels.
- Add accessible curb ramps along Crystal St at all intersections and marked crosswalks.
- Upgrade existing crosswalks to meet current accessibility standards with curb ramps and detectable warning strips.
- Initiate formal feasibility study of a walking route/multi-use path to connect open space and historic assets along the Housatonic River with other neighboring communities.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider adding sidewalks or pedestrian lane pavement markings on residential streets with high volumes of pedestrians and relatively high volumes of vehicles driving quickly (e.g., Patterson Rd to Montessori School, Catherine St, Golden Hill Rd north of Lasher Lane).
- Deliberately design roadways that will remain shared with no pavement markings delineating space for user groups (e.g., Lawton St, Henry Ave, School St, Old Town Way).
- Consider narrowing travel lanes (no wider than 11') by repainting fog lines on Crystal St.
- Work with Lenox police department to evaluate reported speeding issues on Crystal St; initiate speed enforcement patrols periodically if driver behavior warrants them.
- Include sidewalk extension along Golden Hill Rd to Henry Ave as part of the Walker St reconstruction project.
- Evaluate whether sidewalks are needed or feasible along or at the Catherine St/Golden Hill Rd intersection.
- Evaluate whether any of the residential streets need sidewalks based on dangerous walking conditions or high pedestrian and vehicular traffic volumes.
- Include construction of accessible curb ramps and a crosswalk on Crystal St at the bus stop in the current Crystal St resurfacing project.
- Install advance crosswalk signs and pedestrian crossing signs at existing crosswalks.
- Consider additional crosswalks on Crystal St north of the Post Office, if needed near other entrance roads along the east side of Crystal St.
- Study need for additional crosswalks at the Walker St/Mill St/Crystal St intersection. One may be needed if a walking route is established along Crystal St reaching into town-owned land along an easement on the west side of the Housatonic River beyond the intersection with Walker St.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Elm St, Crystal St, Mill St, Walker St, Golden Hill Rd, Catherine St
THEMES: Accessibility, Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: On Tuesday, September 19, 2017, WalkBoston conducted a walk audit on High Street with support from the Massachusetts Executive Office of Public Safety and Security (EOPSS) Pedestrian Safety Planning Initiative for High-Fatality Communities. The goal of the walk assessment was to recommend improvements to the local built environment that improve pedestrian safety.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install traffic signals equipped with accessible pedestrian countdown signals
- Replace all sidewalk panels in need with concrete sidewalks
- Ensure that all ramps are compliant with ADA standards and add detectable warnings and level landings
- Raise curbs to provide 6" reveal between the roadway and sidewalk
- Reduce the extensive curb cuts leading to businesses and surface parking along the west side of High St
- Paint the "Ls and Ts" to delineate parking spaces and bus stops on the roadway
- Install curb bump outs at the mid-block crossing in front of the Norton Family Manor
- Consider installing a Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacon (RRFB) in front of the Norton Family Manor
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install highly visible STOP signs on all approaches; move or replace STOP sign on northbound High Street approach
- Paint STOP lines to indicate the location where drivers are required to stop
- Install school zone flasing beacons along E Merrimack St and High St
- Repair/replace sidewalk panels in dire need of repair, such as near mature trees
- Enforce parking regulations; issue tickets to those in violation
- Paint diagonal lines and install flex posts indicating no parking zones at intersections and near mid-block crossing
- Install No Parking signs
- Install curb ramps to access mid-block crossing in front of the Norton Family Manor
- Extend the pedestrian phase so pedestrians can cross the High/Andover intersection diagonally
- Consider adding additional time to the all RED phase to allow cars to clear the intersection

SUMMARY: The Drum Hill Road/Westford Street Walk Audit, conducted by WalkMass through the Mass in Motion program, assessed walkability and pedestrian safety along a key corridor connecting Chelmsford and Lowell, MA. Participants documented challenges such as high traffic speeds, inadequate crosswalks, and poor pedestrian visibility, which limit safe access to nearby residences, businesses, and retail spaces. The findings aim to guide improvements in walkability and pedestrian infrastructure for a safer, more accessible environment.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Narrow travel lanes on Technology Dr to 10 feet during repaving to reduce vehicle speeds.
- Add curb extensions and tighten radii to slow turns, enhance pedestrian visibility, and shorten crossings.
- Ensure development projects require property owners to build and maintain sidewalks and connections to neighboring properties.
- Redesign the intersection to improve pedestrian safety by realigning Parkhurst Road to meet Drum Hill Road at a 90-degree angle, removing signalization at the Gulf Station driveway, tightening curb radii, and adding pedestrian signals and crosswalks.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add a raised crosswalk and MUTCD-compliant pedestrian signage at 55 Technology Dr.
- Repaint crosswalks, assess adding a traffic signal with pedestrian features, improve visibility by adjusting the stone wall, and repair sidewalks for better accessibility on Technology Dr.
- Repair the pedestrian signal at the crosswalk infront of Walmart, update signage to MUTCD standards, and install continuous 5’ sidewalks with tree-lined buffers along Westford Street/Drum Hill Road.
- Add a crosswalk to improve pedestrian visibility at the Gulf Gas Station driveway and trim vegetation .
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED:
Technology Dr, Drum Hill Rd, Westford St, & Intersection of Drum Hill Rd & Westford
St

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit along a route incorporating a section of downtown Lynn in response to the city's growing concerns about bicycle and pedestrian safety. Key observations from participants include outdated equipment and signage, a lack of ADA compliancy, and an overall difficulty for pedestrians and road users alike to navigate crossings and intersections.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Evaluate traffic directional patterns on Central Ave and throughout the city to maximize pedestrian safety while maintaining reasonable traffic flows and limiting vehicular back-ups
- Evaluate traffic patterns in and around City Hall Square for ways to improve pedestrian safety
- Consider a concurrent phase pedestrian traffic signal with a leading pedestrian indicator; one-way traffic patterns should make concurrent phase possible
- Evaluate the safety implications of marking a crosswalk across Central Ave at Sutton St; paint a crosswalk across Sutton St at Central Ave
- Install ADA-compliant curb ramps and detectable warning strips
- Reduce curb radius on northeast corner of Central/Liberty St intersection to shorten crossing distance
- Add pedestrian push button-activated pedestrian phase to flashing traffic signal at Oxford/Central to provide a protected crossing phase
- Do a comprehensive review of pedestrian crossings and desire lines
- Evaluate location of existing crosswalks based on pedestrian desire lines and legal vehicular traffic movements in Linnehan Square
- Review street network and traffic flows (one-way vs two-way) to determine if vehicular cut-through behavior can be modified
- Repair or replace curb ramps and detectable warning strips where needed
- Evaluate the safety of painting a mid-block crosswalk across Central Ave between Linnehan Square and Central Square
- Evaluate light conditions under overpass at night and install lighting to improve visibility for drivers and pedestrians
- Study Freeman Square traffic patterns and redesign square with appropriate pedestrian refuge islands and traffic medians that clarify traffic movements, protect pedestrians at street crossings, and improve functionality of vehicular traffic flow
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Use pavement markings and paint to narrow travel lanes and slow traffic; paint parking lanes or edge lines.
- Repair pedestrian traffic signal so that it faces the pedestrians using it in City Hall Square.
- Paint or repaint crosswalks with ladder or continental designs and stop lines.
- Work with business owner on southwest corner to delineate walking zone from parking zone at Central and Sutton.
- Remove parking at southwest corner of Sutton/Central to increase pedestrian visibility.
- Paint crosswalk between curb ramps on Central Ave and limit parking within 20' of crosswalk.
- Remove diagonal crosswalk at Central/Washington in Olympia Square and relocate along Central Ave before intersection with Andrew St.
- Paint stop bar with a STOP legend on the pavement and add stop sign to the left sign to increase compliance with stop sign.
- Repair or replace pedestrian traffic signal at Oxford and Central Ave.
- Evaluate location of senior crossing sign and either remove it or add crosswalk.
- Upgrade traffic island in Linnehan Square and/or install bump-outs to shorten crossing distances and make pedestrians more visible and movements more predictable in the square; ADA-compliant curb ramps and detectable warning strips may be needed.
- Use in-street pedestrian signs to help alert drivers to presence of crosswalks.
- Install additional "yield to pedestrian" signs, roadside pedestrian crossing signs, and/or in-street pedestrian signs to help alert drivers to presence of crosswalks.
- Remove on-street parking along Union St nearest to the curve to improve motorists' visibility of pedestrians; consider using an in-street pedestrian sign.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Central Avenue, Essex St, North and South Common St, Market St, Sutton St, Liberty St, Washington St, Oxford St, Andrew St, Willow St, Blake St, Munroe St, Union St, Buffumm St, Baldwin St

SUMMARY: School Street connects Route 128 to Route 127, Manchester’s “Main Street,” and because it is one of the town’s connecting streets it carries fairly heavy traffic traveling at speeds that make walking uncomfortable. Because School Street provides walking access to the community's elementary, middle, and high schools, there is great interest in increasing pedestrian safety along the street
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install stop signs at Pleasant, Lincoln, Vine, and Brook St to slow traffic, improve yielding behavior by drivers, and discourage the use of School St by large trucks
- Fix curb ramps at each street crossing, tighten turning radius at each intersection, and add bump outs at locations with crosswalks
- Add raised crosswalks if needed once previous improvements are in place
- Install pedestrian scale lighting along School St which will add a visual cue to drivers that they are in a zone where walkers are expected
- Reconfigure the School/127 intersection to as tight an angle as possible to significantly reduce the crossing distance for both School St and Route 127
- Seek approval to use mid-block crossing sign on Route 127 at School St
- Complete the sidewalk where it is missing on the east side of School St near Sawmill Brook
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install in-street "Yield to Pedestrian" signs in the crosswalks at Pleasant, Lincoln, Vine, and Brook St to slow traffic and improve yielding behaviors by drivers
- At each crosswalk on School St, do no allow parking within 20' of the crosswalk on either side of the crosswalk by painting pavement markings; daylighting the crossing area will make pedestrians more visible to drivers and give pedestrians better sight lines to see approaching traffic
- Enforce no parking on sidewalk regulations along School St
- Re-stripe School St by shifting the double yellow line to allow one 10' southbound lane, one 10' northbound lane, and a 7' striped parking lane on the west side of the street
- Reduce the width of the curb cut on School St near Route 127 to make the sidewalk safer, and move the mailboxes to a new location while adding a stop sign and in-street yield to pedestrian signs to make the crossing there safer
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: School St, Route 128, Route 127
THEMES: Age Friendly , "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: In partnership with the Mass in Motion program, a walk audit in Manchester-by-the-Sea focused on the area between Manchester Memorial Elementary School and the village center. Key issues identified include narrow sidewalks, low-visibility crosswalks, and insufficient signage, impacting access to schools, the commuter rail, and local businesses. With 20.6% of residents being children and upcoming school renovations requiring new routes, the project aims to improve pedestrian safety and accessibility for all.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Improve pedestrian visibility at the Union Street - Beach Street intersection.
- Ensure that hedges and other plantings along sidewalks remain clear of the sidewalk and that no other materials infringe on pedestrian space.
- Implement plans from the Complete Streets proposal for this intersection.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Implement strategies to reduce traffic speeds on School Street. Enforce maximum lane widths of
10 feet on School Street.
-Install clearly marked crosswalks in front of schools with visible signage.
- Organize a student walk audit to better understand what challenges children encounter on their walks to school.
- Implement projects to paint streets along popular routes to school with a playful, colorful pattern that notify vehicles that children may be walking in the street.
- Notify households surrounding the school that they should keep their sidewalks clear of plantings and other items.
- Undertake a tactical urbanism project to expand the median and extend the curbs, informally and impermanently narrowing the driving lanes.

SUMMARY: Participants met near the corner of Salem and Vine St before walking along Salem St to observe existing pedestrian conditions and discuss some of the opportunities to improve the safety and attractiveness of the street for people walking. This audit, along with city residents, was conducted with members of MassDOT Safe Routes to School, Walk Medford, and Mass in Motion.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Fix uneven and broken sidewalks to create a level walking path
- Clear or provide smooth, graded asphalt path over tree roots
- Add bump-arounds to add accessible sidewalks where there are large trees blocking the sidewalk
- Re-grade driveways to make a level sidewalk
- Re-build intersections and crosswalks to enhance walking:
- Add bumpouts to reduce crossing distances and enhance visibility
- Tighten curb radii at all corners to shorten crossing distances and slow turning vehicles
- Wherever possible, construct curb ramps at right angles into crosswalks, not angled on corners (apex ramps)
- Work with business owners to narrow curb cuts into parking or service areas and thus slow turning vehicles and reduce pedestrian exposure to turning vehicles.
- Create site plan regulations requiring minimal and narrow curb cuts across thesidewalk.
- Install pedestrian friendly street lighting.
- Set most traffic signals with concurrent WALK lights (with pedestrians walking while traffic moves in the same direction) that include Leading Pedestrian Indicators (LPIs) which give walkers a head start across the intersection. Intersections where this may not be appropriate include locations with heavy turning movements (250+/hour) or near schools or senior housing.
- Work with Target to provide a safe and attractive walking route across the parking lot to the front door of the store. We observed many pedestrians crossing the lot without a clear path or any protections from traffic.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add in-street vertical “Yield to Pedestrian” signs; consider asking local businesses or residents to sponsor or adopt the signs – to set them up if they are knocked over, bring them inside if it snows, and let the City know if the sign needs to be replaced.
- Repaint cross walks with reflective paint to add visibility.
- Add shark’s teeth markings at mid-block crossings (if any are added in the future).
- Provide signage and pavement marking to pull parking back at least 20 feet from all crosswalks (from the approaching direction
of vehicles) to increase visibility of pedestrians who are crossing the street – important for walkers to see vehicles and for drivers to see people crossing. Because this will result in the loss of some parking spaces, it will require a community outreach and engagement process. Consider beginning with the school community and Walk Medford to enlist local supporters.
- Add ‘fog lines” or parking space lines to perceptually narrow the travel lanes and thus slow traffic.
- Use paint and flex posts to tighten curb radii to shorten crossing distances and slow vehicles as they are turning.
- Where construction projects are underway (e.g. Everett Street) work immediately with City staff and developers to tighten curb radii as part of the development process.
- Straighten angled crosswalks where possible to reduce crossing distances.
- Mill the edges of slightly uneven sidewalk pavers to reduce tripping hazards (this cannot provide adequate repairs where the pavers are significantly uneven or broken, but can deal with smaller uneven spots).
- Add speed feedback signs in locations where vehicle speeds are the highest/problematic. Research suggests that these signs provide the most significant benefits shortly after they are installed and that they should be used on a temporary basis.
- Plant new trees where possible without narrowing the sidewalk – consider working with adjacent property owners to plant trees on private property adjacent to the sidewalk.
- Maintain and install benches, and consider working with adjacent property owners to place benches on private property adjacent to the sidewalk. Install benches with armrests to ensure that they serve people of all ages and physical abilities.
- Consider implementing a pilot intersection improvement at Hadley Place/Salem Street to demonstrate many of the short term improvements such as temporary bulb outs, signage and pavement markings, and use of flex posts to create tight turning radii.
- To ensure that busy pedestrian routes remain accessible after snow storms – for examples on walk-to-school routes or along bus corridors – the City might take responsibility for ensuring that curb ramps and bus stops are well cleared. This can be implemented along the same streets and sidewalks where property owners remain responsible for sidewalk snow shoveling.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Salem St, Haines Square, Everett St
THEMES: Connectivity, Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Age Friendly , Accessibility, Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted a walkability assessment in Melrose, Massachusetts, near Lincoln Elementary School. The assessment focused on pedestrian safety and routes students use to walk to and from school. After an initial discussion of safety concerns and the assessment process, the group performed an on-the-street audit of the area's pedestrian facilities.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Raise crosswalks near Lincoln Elementary (speed tables) and add advance signage to alert drivers.
- Relocate the crosswalk east of the school driveway to the west to avoid crossing over the driveway.
- Tighten corners at Pleasant and West Wyoming to reduce turning speeds.
- Install curb ramps, signage, and a crosswalk connecting the Lincoln School fields and the apartment walkway on Pleasant Street.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Place pedestrian crossing signage in the center of the roadway year-round to increase driver awareness of pedestrians.
- Install ADA-compliant curb ramps at crosswalks near Lincoln Elementary.
- Add "STOP" signs and paint stop bars near Everett Street to slow drivers before crosswalks.
- Install signage and pavement markings indicating a school zone and pedestrian presence.
- Re-direct or contain the downspout with a rain barrel to prevent walkway drainage issues.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Lincoln Elementary School
THEMES: Youth, Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY:

friendly policies, and education and encouragement programs that will encourage more students (and staff) to ride bicycles or walk to school. WalkBoston and WatsonActive observed Middle School/High School arrival on April 25 and 27, 2017. The City Engineer requested a preliminary report recommending a project for  possible inclusion in the City’s Complete Streets Prioritization Plan. WalkBoston and WatsonActive delivered a report of infrastructure recommendations for Melrose Street on April 28, 2017.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider limiting left turns out of The Knoll at dismissal time
- Continue to educate students on the importance of using crosswalks to walk across the Parkway 
- Consider the feasibility of constructing a bike path between the sidewalk and staff parking lot
- Install a new crosswalk, required curb ramps, and detectable warning panels across Melrose St on the north side of the staff parking lot entrance; place an in-street pedestrian
- Close/block off the drop-off loop located on the school-side of Melrose St between Ashland St and Albion St; place an in-street pedestrian crossing sign in the crosswalk during school arrival and dismissal
- Establish formal drop off zones using signage and potentially pavement markings along the school side of Melrose St
- Prohibit on-street parking at all times on both sides of Melrose St between Lynn Fells Parkway and Tremont St; replace signage accordingly
- Consider installation of standard striped bicycle lanes on both sides of the roadway adjacent to the curb
- Use green pavement coloration and signage where bicycle facilities coincide with designated drop-off zones
- Consider installing curb bump-outs on Lynn Fells Parkway on the west side of the Melrose St intersection
- Consider adding more bike racks and especially more covered bike parking
- Explore feasibility of providing afternoon shuttle service for middle and high school students to common destinations
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint a crosswalk across The Knoll entrance drive
- Consider moving the crosswalk and curb ramps from the north side of Albion St to the south side of Albion St if drop-off loop remains; place an in-street pedestrian crossing sign
- Enhance the crosswalk across Melrose St at Ashland St with upgraded pavement markings

SUMMARY: The City of New Bedford, participating in the Massachusetts Department of Transportation’s Highway Safety Improvement Program, identified high-priority intersections that pose significant risks to pedestrians. WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment in the city's central commercial district, focusing on four particularly dangerous intersections, to explore potential remedies for improving pedestrian safety. This assessment aims to scope out necessary changes and provide actionable recommendations for enhancing safety at these high-risk intersections.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add crosswalk and curb ramps on the north side of the intersection.
- Replace curb and tighten the curb radius at the northeast corner to discourage fast turns.
- Add regulatory signage (one-way, do-not-enter) on Pleasant and Elm Streets.
- Upgrade curb ramps to ADA standards with detectable warning strips.
- Add bump-outs at the south side crosswalks on Elm Street to reduce crossing distance.
- Add edge (fog) lines on the south side of Elm Street to slow traffic or create a bike lane.
- Add a crosswalk over Elm Street at Eighth Street.
- Install mid-block crosswalks and curb ramps on County Street.
- Extend pedestrian signal timing and consider leading pedestrian indicators.
- Add a mid-block crossing of Union Street at Seventh and Eighth Streets with curb ramps.
- Consider traffic calming measures at Market and Pleasant Streets (e.g., curb bump-outs, raised crossings).
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Repair and repaint red bituminous crosswalks for visibility.
- Install pedestrian countdown signals and push buttons on all approaches.
- Paint parking space lines on County Street to narrow travel lanes.
- Upgrade signal equipment with new pedestrian heads and push buttons.
- Add edge (fog) lines on Pleasant Street to slow traffic.
- Add mid-street warning signs at the Market Street intersection.
- Repaint parking spaces for police vehicles away from crosswalks.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: County St, Elm St, Pleasant St, & Union St
THEMES: Accessibility, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY:
South End Engaged, an initiative coordinated by the United Way of Greater New Bedford, hosted a walk
assessment to further the group’s vision for the South End: "All residents of the South End of New Bedford are
safe, healthy, and have the knowledge and skills to thrive." The main goals of the assessment included economic revitalization, family and school engagement, health and safety, and resident organization. WalkBoston conducted the assessment on October 19. 2016, funded by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health Mass in Motion program.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Participate in the planning and design of the South End road reconstruction projects to ensure adequate sidewalk width and connectivity
- Install ADA-compliant curb ramps and detectable warning panels on all approaches to all intersections and mid-block crossings
- Identify partnership and funding opportunities to implement new gateway concept at Grinnell/South 2nd St intersection
- Install pedestrian traffic signals at the Rivet/County St intersection
- Redesign streets within the study area to reduce traffic speeds and provide a safe environment for people walking in the neighborhood
- Consider establishing a slow zone throughout the South End neighborhood; slow zones limit traffic speeds to 20 mph much like a school zone
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Replace sidewalk panels disrupted due to tree roots (New Bedford Department of Public Infrastructure (DPI) has a short-term fix that preserves the tree and provides a smoother sidewalk)
- Replace asphalt sidewalk between Rivet St and Potomska St with a concrete sidewalk
- Motivate residents and property owners to trim vegetation and pick up litter/trash on the sidewalks near their property; neighborhood organizations, faith-based institutions, schools, or social service organizations can be good partners in these efforts
- Activate sidewalks with activity along high-volume pedestrian corridors (e.g. temporary installations, pop-up parks, parklets (temporary seating areas placed in parking spaces in front of businesses to provide outdoor gathering spaces))
- Develop a crosswalk painting plan that prioritizes highly utilized pedestrian corridors and walk-to-school routes
- Paint new high visibility crosswalks at high priority locations; continue with lower priority locations as funding and time allows
- Repaint existing crosswalks with high-visibility crosswalks
- Install school zone beacons and signage along South 2nd St near the Gomes and Renaissance Schools
- Hold community design charrettte/workshop to rethink the connection between the neighborhood and the Gomes/Renaissance Schools at Grinnell St
- Install No Right Turn on Red signs on all approaches at the Rivet/County St intersection to provide some protection for pedestrians crossing without a pedestrian signal
- Engage the city in a conversation regarding the use of concurrent and exclusive signal timing; concurrent signal timing has been shown to increase pedestrian compliance and shorten overall cycle times for all users (recommended except when signals are located within school zones or in areas with high numbers of seniors)
- Work with New Bedford police to monitor and enforce speed limits along Sout 2nd St and County St
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Grinnell St, South 2nd St, South 1st St, Delano St, County St
THEMES: Age Friendly , Accessibility, Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Youth

SUMMARY:
The Acushnet Avenue neighborhood walk assessment supplements the great efforts of the Love the Ave
initiative, facilitated by the Massachusetts Smart Growth Alliance, and the recent City of New Bedford’s
road safety improvements in the neighborhood. WalkBoston connected with the Love the Ave initiative
after a MassDOT Bicycle and Pedestrian Safety Enforcement and Awareness Program follow-up meeting.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider curb bump-outs at intersections with marked crosswalks to shorten crossing distances and improve pedestrian visibility
- Add benches, trees, and trash receptacles along sidewalks
- Add/improve lighting along Acushnet Ave with new light poles or improved fixtures and bulbs
- Upgrade pedestrian signals to countdown signals
- Upgrade crosswalks with pavers, transverse lines, and detectable warning panels
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint fog lines to delineate the outside edge of travel lanes
- Enhance crossings with high visibility ladder crosswalks
- Work with the New Bedford Police Department to locate a speed trailer on Belleville Ave to reduce traffic speeds while capturing speed data
- Paint diagonal lines at intersections and near crosswalks to discourage parking within 20'
- Place in-street pedestrian signs in crosswalks to increase awareness of crossing zones
- Install a bus shelter near the Sawyer St/Acushnet Ave intersection
- Study light levels along Acushnet Ave to determine if additional light poles or changes in light fixtures or bulbs would improve conditions
- Evaluate the walk time at both intersections to ensure that there is adequate time to walk across the street before the pedestrian signals change to solid red
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Acushnet Ave, Sawyer St, Belleville Ave, Bullard St
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Bike or Bus

SUMMARY: The City of New Bedford was awarded a Safe Routes to Parks (SRTP) technical assistance grant from the National Parks and Recreation Association. The goal of the SRTP program is to increase safe access to parks and improve health outcomes in underserved areas. Using Ashley Park in New Bedford’s South End Neighborhood as a pilot park, WalkMass worked with New Bedford City staff to develop a process of assessing the walking routes to the park. Lessons learned from this walk audit and pilot project will inform future park evaluations in New Bedford.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Include park entrance redesign, reuse of the softball field, and alternative fencing solutions in the Ashley Park redevelopment scope.
- Redesign the Bolton Street/Rivet Street intersection with curb bump-outs or traffic-calming devices to improve pedestrian safety.
- Install new sidewalks and curbing along Katherine Street near the parking lot and along Bonney Street near the playground, while addressing non-compliant curb ramps.
- Upgrade streetlights to improve illumination across the neighborhood, as identified in evaluations.
- Review zoning codes for potential long-term land-use changes and integrate tree planting strategies within future development plans.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Increase visibility of park entrances by trimming vegetation and installing temporary signage, pavement markings, and seasonal plantings to highlight access points.
- Add missing crosswalks at key crossings and repaint stop lines to improve visibility.
- Repair crumbling sidewalks around Ashley Park and identify areas with missing or non-compliant curb ramps for immediate attention.
- Replace bulbs in existing fixtures on the Community Center and add a light fixture to the softball pole to brighten the northeast corner of the park.
- Enforce parking restrictions and determine feasibility of street tree planting along Bolton Street.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Ashley Park
THEMES: Age Friendly , Comfort & Safety, Schools, Connectivity

- Locate APS pushbuttons adjacent to the curb ramps and clear of other street furniture wherever possible
- Reivew the feasibility of a road diet to remove a travel lane, reducing the cross-section to a single travel lane in each direction with a center turning lane
- Revise crosswalk standards to include parallel lines
- Install pedestrian scale lighting
- Install a high-visibility crosswalk across Walker St with enhanced features such as a rapid flashing beacon and curb extensions
- Coordinate with MBTA to relocate or consolidate bus stops
- Consider installing a multi-space parking meter on the south side of Washington St to encourage Post Office visitors to cross at the crosswalk
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Provide ADA-compliant curb ramps including detectable warning panels at all crosswalks
- Maintain minimum ADA clearance on all sidewalks through widening or removal of obstacles
- Conduct a parking utilization study
- Connect the sidewalk gaps on Walker St
- Stripe crosswalks across Walker St
- Upgrade drainage to reduce ponding in curb ramps
- Install NO TURN ON RED signage for the southbound approach at the Washington/Walnut intersection
- Install confirmation light and accessible push buttons at intersections
- Remove parking to extend the bus stop at the Washington St/Harvard Ave intersection

SUMMARY: Participants gathered in the Waverly Road neighborhood north of Massachusetts Avenue to walk a two-mile loop down streets that had been identified as high-risk for crashes or had a history of crashes with injury outcomes. Residents who joined the walk shared observations and advised potential countermeasures. In addition to the residents, Merrimack Valley Planning Commission Staff, NA Planning Board member and MVPC Commissioner Eitan Goldman, and Merrimack Valley Consultant BETA attended the walk.

- Study for Stop sign implementation on Marblehead Street
- Add curb extensions on SW and SE corners of Waverly Road and Middlesex Street
- Convert parallel parking to angle parking on Middlesex across from Market
- Add raised median on Waverly 
- Improve/repave sidewalks along Waverly
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Daylight all crosswalks
- Repaint double yellow centerline and fog lines to narrow lanes on Marblehead and Middlesex Streets
- Improve wayfinding for pedestrians to navigate neighborhood
- Raise Stop signs to 7' from bottom of sign on Waverly and Middlesex Roads

SUMMARY: The Hilltown CDC, in partnership with Healthy Hampshire and WalkMass, is leading a 5-year project to promote Age-Friendly Walkability in Hilltown Village Centers, including Plainfield. The project involves conducting walk audits to identify infrastructure improvements and policy changes to make walking safer and more enjoyable for people of all ages. Plainfield faces challenges such as fast-moving traffic, a lack of sidewalks, and unsafe crossing areas, but upcoming projects, including a pedestrian-only zone and traffic calming measures, are set to enhance pedestrian safety and walkability in the town.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
-Tighten the curb radii and provide safe crossingsby reducing width of the intersection by redesigning the street with narrower travel lanes and less asphalt, and RRFB.
- Install a sidewalk with raised crosswalks to slow traffic and maintain a consistent elevation for pedestrians.
- Explore options for placemaking and increased pedestrian safety around the new village green project.
- Evaluate and explore options to improve pedestrian access and safety along and across Route 116 to reach the Congregational Church, Post Office, and parking areas.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
-Tighten the curb radii and provide safe crossings by painting curb bump outs that narrow travel lanes and crosswalks to promote slower travel speeds and provide people walking with marked crossings.
- Determine the right-of-way dimensions along this stretch of road to clarify ownership, and post advisory signage for pedestrians and use paint to narrow lanes, encouraging slower driving.
- Update existing speed feedback signs to provide positive feedback.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Intersection of Central/Main St, Main St, Union St, & Intersection of Union/Main St
THEMES: Age Friendly , "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Accessibility

- Reconstruct pedestrian islands with wider safety areas and place walk activation lights directly adjacent to the pedestrian island

SUMMARY:
The Beachmont Improvement Committee (BIC) and City of Revere Staff identified Cummings
Square as an area in need of improved walking infrastructure given the number of pedestrians
moving through the square, its proximity to Beachmont Veterans Memorial School, and the
fast-moving traffic experienced by neighborhood residents. Walk audit participants were particularly concerned with the lack of crosswalks, pavement markings, and ADA compliancy.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install curb ramps and/or replace non-compliant curb ramps at any remaining Crescent Ave and Winthrop Ave corners that are not repaired as part of current road repair project. Install detectable warning panels
- Consider re-routing traffic around Cummings Square in a one-way loop. This strategy could remove some of the confusion drivers now experience when driving in this area. It could also provide opportunities to reclaim some of the pavement with expanded curb bump-outs that would shorten crossing distances for people walking and reduce traffic speeds. It would require the reallocation of some parking spaces
- Conduct parking utilization study to determine need and desired location of parking around Cummings Square
- If needed, conduct a study of light levels around Cummings Square to inform a pedestrian scale lighting strategy
- Install sidewalk within the traffic island at the Crescent Ave/Orchard St intersection and add crosswalks and functional curb ramps
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint parking lanes or “Ts and Ls” along Winthrop Avenue to narrow travel lane and
delineate parking zones
- Paint high visibility crosswalks (continental or ladder) across Crescent Avenue at Belle Isle Avenue on the west side of the intersection, and a crosswalk at the stop sign at the intersection of Crescent Avenue and Winthrop Avenue. Vehicular traffic must stop at this location already and are more likely to see pedestrians crossing here than at a mid-block, uncontrolled crossing across Winthrop at the east side of Cummings Square.
- Repaint all crosswalks in the area with high visibility crosswalks (continental or ladder).
- Where possible given current street projects, install curb ramps and/or replace non-
compliant curb ramps Crescent Avenue and Winthrop Avenue corners. Install detectable warning panels.
- Paint stop lines where they are missing and refresh existing stop lines.
- Use Ts and Ls to delineate parking spaces around Cummings Square. Ensure spaces are marked a sufficient distance away from crosswalks (approx. 20’-25’).
- Investigate the history of the highway scale safety barrier. Its presence conveys danger.
- Observe quality of street light levels at night around Cummings Square and at major
crossing points.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Cummings Square, Crescent Ave, Winthrop Ave, Orchard St
THEMES: Accessibility, Schools, Comfort & Safety, Connectivity, Youth, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted this walk assessment as part of the Massachusetts Department of Transportation Bicycle and Pedestrian Safety Program, in collaboration with the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. As a pedestrian advocacy organization, WalkMass aims to make walking safer and easier in Massachusetts to promote health, environmental sustainability, and community vitality. The assessment focused on building awareness and understanding of the pedestrian environment at both state and local levels.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Move curb lines to permanently narrow travel lanes and redesign intersections with tighter curb radii and curb extensions.
- Rebuild sidewalks with wider walkways, grass buffers, and pedestrian-friendly designs.
- Install Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacons (RRFBs), HAWK signals, or push-button pedestrian signals where necessary.
- Redesign medians to function as pedestrian refuge islands.
- Improve the "Kiss and Ride" zone with curb extensions and a formalized drop-off area.
- Upgrade crosswalks to stamped or brick-like treatments consistent with the historic district.
- Reconfigure slip lanes, consider prohibiting Right Turn on Red (RTOR), and improve signage for driver compliance.
- Evaluate and redesign traffic signal operations and medians for improved pedestrian safety and traffic flow.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint edge lines or fog lines to narrow travel lanes on Washington and Bridge Streets.
- Add crosswalks, repaint existing crosswalks with ladder or continental designs, and improve pavement markings.
- Install "Children Crossing," "Yield to Pedestrian," and other pedestrian warning signs where needed.
- Repair or relocate signs, trim vegetation, and address visibility issues at intersections and medians.
- Remove parking spaces within 20 feet of crosswalks to improve pedestrian visibility.
- Improve sidewalk conditions, repair curb ramps, and ensure ADA compliance with detectable warning strips.
- Adjust pedestrian signal timing to ensure adequate crossing time and evaluate concurrent phases where possible.
- Add lighting under the Bridge Street overpass for pedestrian and driver visibility.
- Provide wayfinding signage and clarify "Don't Block the Box" pavement markings.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Intersections of Washington Street/Bridge Street, North Street/Federal Street, Summer Street/Chestnut Street/ Norman Street, and Washington Street/New Derby Street
THEMES: Age Friendly , Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Youth

SUMMARY: On May 6, 2015, WalkBoston participated in a walk audit on the Salem State University (SSU) campus around the O’Keefe Center and the edges of North Campus. John Pelletier, Mass in Motion Coordinator for the City of Salem, led the audit and the participants included SSU staff, neighborhood advocates, city staff and city council members. The goal of the audit was to discuss the safety and quality of the pedestrian environment along the walk route and recommend improvements that would enhance the pedestrian experience.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Prioritize the replacement of sidewalks on Atlantic St, Linden St, Broadway, and Loring Ave; install ADA-compliant curb ramps and detectable warning panels at all intersections
- Work with business owners and residences to reduce driveway widths and curb radii where possible
- Work with Salem police to discourage parking on sidewalks and within pedestrian pathways along Broadway
- Hire a traffic engineer to study possible reconfigurations of the Broadway/Canal St intersection
- Minimize number and width of curb cuts along Loring Ave and reduce curb radii on driveways where possible
- Determine if a pedestrian traffic signal is needed at the Rainbow Terrace/Loring Ave intersection; if needed, replace the antiquated pedestrian traffic signal
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider installing slow zone signs to reduce traffic speeds at the Loring Ave/Linden St crossing
- Evaluate the Atlantic/Linden/Day intersection to determine if other approaches, in addition to the eastbound Atlantic approach, need traffic control signs
- Reduce or reconfigure parking along the streets in the O'Keefe Center to North Campus corridor to improve visibility at intersections
- Paint crosswalks and add ADA-compliant curb ramps across Charles St and Wisteria at their intersections with Linden Ave
- Improve the visibility of the crosswalks across Loring St and Linden St at the Linden St intersection; improve pavement markings to a ladder or continental style crosswalk, upgrade the in-street pedestrian sign in the crosswalk, and improve street lighting
- Prohibit parking within 20' of the crosswalk across Loring to improve visibility
- Assess the volume of users of the crosswalk near the Raymond Rd/Loring Ave intersection; if low, remove crosswalk to limit the number of crosswalks along this corridor
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Atlantic St, Loring Ave, Rainbow Terrace, Broadway, Canal St, Linden St
THEMES: Connectivity, Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Accessibility

SUMMARY: The audit, supported by Mass in Motion, aimed to promote active transportation and recommend improvements to enhance walkability and safety. Participants included WalkMass, Salem departments, community organizations, and residents. The Point, a diverse neighborhood with many D.R and Caribbean immigrants, is home to the Punto Urban Art Museum. With more visitors and planned development, improving walkability is crucial for health and safety.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Improve conditions of sidewalks and curb ramps for accessibility and ADA compliance.
- Use daylighting and bumpouts/curb extensions at crosswalks to enhance visibility, reduce crossing distances, and calm traffic.
- Improve pedestrian access and connectivity to parks and public spaces throughout the neighborhood.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add and upgrade crosswalks with fresh paint, highly visible ladder designs, and signage.
- Provide more trash receptacles for neighborhood cleanliness and beautification.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Lafayette St, Peabody St, Ward St,  Congress St, & Lynch St
THEMES: Connectivity, Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: A walk audit in North Salem, conducted through the Mass in Motion program, assessed walking conditions along North Street, Buffum Street, Franklin Street, and key neighborhood paths. The area, which saw 11 pedestrian crashes between 2009-2019, including one fatality, highlights safety concerns for those accessing businesses, schools, and the MBTA commuter rail. Residents seek improvements to make their neighborhood safer and more pedestrian-friendly.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Implement infrastructure improvements like narrowing approaches at intersections with curb bump-outs or refuge islands, redesigning North Street for safer crossings and slower traffic, developing a sidewalk network along Franklin and Appleton Streets, and enhancing the North Street bridge underpass for better pedestrian access.
- Enact policy changes and urban design updates to minimize driveway curb cuts, prioritize pedestrian zones, and explore shared-use street concepts for Randall Street.
- Manage traffic more effectively by studying the impact of closing Randall Street to through traffic, implementing traffic calming measures like speed tables on Buffum Street, and ensuring any one-way conversion includes safety adjustments.
- Enhance connectivity by planning development of the parking lot at Franklin Street to improve MBTA access and implementing wayfinding signage for the MBTA and other destinations.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Improve crosswalks by moving obstructed signage at Osborne Street, adding enhancements like curb bump-outs and RRFBs, and installing new crosswalks at Randall Street and Appleton Street with visibility improvements.
- Enhance sidewalks by trimming overgrown vegetation on Randall and Buffum Streets and reducing sidewalk clutter like signage and receptacles.
- Address immediate safety concerns by evaluating traffic signal timing at key intersections, enforcing parking regulations to improve visibility, improving lighting along paths near the MBTA Commuter Rail Station, and clearing debris and overgrowth from the riverside walking path.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED:
North St, Mason St, Buffum St,  Randall St, & Intersection of North St and Orne St/
School St
THEMES: Connectivity, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted this assessment as part of the Massachusetts Department of Transportation Bicycle and Pedestrian Safety Program, in partnership with the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. WalkMass, a pedestrian advocacy organization, aims to make walking safer and easier to promote better health, cleaner environments, and vibrant communities. The assessment's purpose was to build knowledge and awareness of pedestrian conditions at both state and local levels.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Conduct a comprehensive study of pedestrian traffic patterns around the school
- Install zebra or ladder crosswalk markings to raise awareness and improve pedestrian safety
- Implement traffic calming strategies on Medford Street
- Evaluate bus stop locations and move to far side if appropriate
- Evaluate and upgrade all curb ramps for ADA compliance
- Consider installing pedestrian refuge islands and redesign intersections for safer crossings
- Conduct an ongoing review of school zone signage and pavement markings
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Repair curb ramps and install detectable warning strips for ADA compliance
- Repaint faded crosswalks and evaluate crosswalk locations for improvement
- Install accessible curb ramps at all corners
- Relocate bus stop if possible to improve right-of-way
- Install pedestrian countdown signals
- Install curb bump-outs on Pearl and Walnut Street to slow traffic and improve visibility
- Evaluate signal phasing for concurrent phase or Leading Pedestrian Interval (LPI)
- Repaint pavement markings (crosswalks, centerlines, stop lines
