SUMMARY: On March 26, 2013, WalkBoston conducted a walk audit at the German Gerena Community School, an elementary school in Springfield, MA. The audit focused on three major areas: Birnie Avenue, crossing Main Street to the tunnel entrance on the east side of the school, and crossing Plainfield Street to the tunnel entrance on the west side of the school.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install speed tables and perhaps a sandwich board near the Huntington/Birnie and Arch/Birnie Ave crossings
- Either eliminate turn lanes and/or put in medians to protect walkers across Plainfield; the street is unnecessarily wide at the intersection near the school with additional width for turning lanes
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint a stripe on the roadway a couple of feet in front of the Birnie curb in the western travel lane to reduce its width
- Paint SCHOOL ZONE in large letters on the pavement near walking access points to school
- Create curb extensions on either side of the crosswalk at the Main St crossing so cars cannot part next to the crosswalk and students can be more visible to cars
- Paint ladder crosswalks across Plainfield St
- Provide an additional crosswalk and traffic signal on the north side of the drivveway to Chestnut School
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Birnie Ave, Huntington St, Arch St, Main St, Plainfield St
THEMES: Schools, Accessibility, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Youth

SUMMARY: The walk audit was conducted near the Elias Brookings School in Springfield at the request of the Mass in Motion coordinator. The area has challenging walking conditions, with narrow sidewalks, free right-turn lanes, and limited pedestrian safety features. Recommendations include addressing pedestrian issues in upcoming infrastructure projects and improving sidewalks and intersections near the school.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Reduce traffic speed along the walking route, particularly on Walnut Street.
- Redesign intersections to ensure safe crossing points, limit vehicular lanes, and eliminate free-right turning lanes.
- Incorporate roadside verges during streetscape updates to provide space for snow storage and increase separation between pedestrians and vehicles.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add ladder-style crosswalks to increase pedestrian visibility and driver awareness.
- Paint solid white lines (fog lines) parallel to the curb on Walnut and Hancock Streets to narrow perceived lane width and slow traffic.
- Use traffic calming measures like bulb-outs, traffic tables, or flashing pedestrian crossing signs at major Walnut Street crossings to slow cars and enhance pedestrian safety.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED:
Marshall St, Eastern Ave, Hickory St, Hancock St, Walnut St, Intersection of Hickory/
Walnut/Allen Street, Intersection of Hickory/Hancock/Central St, Intersection of Hancock/Walnut/
Ashley/Alden, Intersection of Melrose St/Eastern Avenue
THEMES: Schools, Youth, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety "

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit on September 10, 2013, at the request of the Boland Elementary School Principal Lisa Bakowsi and Springfield Mass in Motion Coordinator, Nicole Bourdon. Several teachers and parents were interested in initiating a Walking School Bus for students along Stafford Road. The school walk audit was seen as a complimentary exercise to evaluate and suggest recommendations for the proposed route and for improvements on other roadways and intersections around the school. The Walking School Bus was successfully launched on International Walk to School Day, on October 9, 2013.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Redesign Carew/Prospect intersection with tightened  curb radii, a more generous traffic island, and marked street crossings
- Prioritize the Carew/Prospect intersection for an engineering study to improve pedestrian safety
- Install a raised crosswalk when the school drive road is resurfaced
- Consider reconfiguring car spacing in the parking area behind the school when the parking lots are resurfaced to provide safer pedestrian corridors on medians or along fence lines
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Increase the number of crosswalks across Stafford St and Nursery St and implement them with a ladder design and pedestrian crossing signs; additional crosswalks should be painted at the entry and exit drives to Mercy Medical Center and across Leslie, Wolcott, and Goodrich St
- Install additional signs (i.e. pedestrian crossing, speed limit, school zone) on Stafford St and Armory St
- Stripe Carew St with bike lanes
- Paint fog lines along the edges of Armory St to help reduce traffic speeds and discourage pull offs and temporary parking
- Replace the pedestrian crossing signal at the Armory/Carew intersection with countdown signals
- Paint a crosswalk in the school parking lot along the pedestrian route leading form the school to the fields
- Paint lines to indicate a driving lane at a recommended width of 10-10.5' to narrow the driver's perception of the road width and help reduce speeds at the one-way vehicular loop beginning and ending at the Stafford St entrance; implement temporary measures to pinch the road width a tthe crosswalk on the exit drive such as tirees, orange barrels with pedestrian crossing signs, or other means to further slow speeds
- Delineate pedestrian crossing points in the parking lots behind the schools with improvements like pavement markings and pedestrian crossing signage
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Armory St, Carew St, Stafford St, Liberty St, Cleveland St, Prospect St
THEMES: Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Bike or Bus, Youth, Connectivity

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit on February 10, 2014 in the Pine Point neighborhood of Springfield, MA in reponse to safety concerns regarding Hiram L. Dorman Elementary School students crossing unprotected streets to reach school.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install curb ramps and detectable warning strips at all marked crossings
- Study feasibility of adding bike lane or sharrow markings on Berkshire
- Explore the possibility of installing speed tables at the intersections of Marsden and Berkshire and/or Jasper and Berkshire
- Install sidewalks and curbs along the one side of Hood St
- Install sidewalks on the east (school side) of Nathaniel St
- Install continuous sidewalks on the west side of Fisher St from Hood St to Pelham St
- Meet with city officials (Department of Public Works, Parks Department, Planning Department, Police Department, School Department, Health Department) to discuss infrastructure needs and advocate for funding to be set aside to address pedestrian safety issues around Dorman School
- Investigate the road resurfacing and reconstruction projects planned for the Dorman School area and ensure that pedestrian infrastructre is part of the new designs
- Address the high impact, low cost solutions first (e.g. painting crosswalks and lane lines)
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint fog lines on Bay St and Berkshire Ave to define lines and narrow perception of lane width
- Upgrade all marked crossings from the standard crosswalk design to a ladder crosswalk design
- Install pedestrian WALK signals to the existing traffic signal heads on both Bay St and Berkshire Ave; study the implications of a protected and push-button-operated pedestrian-only phase on traffic flow and pedestrian safety
- Install pedestrian crossing signs along Bay St and Berkshire Ave to better highlight crossings
- Study the feasibility of installing a pedestrian hybrid beacon at the Bay/Haskin intersection
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Berkshire Ave, Bay St, Fisher St, Nathaniel St, Eastland St,  Haskin St
THEMES: Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Youth
FACILITATOR\/AUTHOR: Dorothea Hass, Stacey Beuttell, Sam Sklar

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit along a proposed walking school bus route along Union St on July 21, 2014 to see if the proposed route would act as a tool to combat low attendance and frequent absences at the Milton Bradley Elementary School.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Enforce ordinances which require vegetation to be trimmed along sidewalks.
- Discuss cleaning up vacant lot on Union St with property owner.
- Consider building a sidewalk to the north of the school's Union St parking lot to provide safe access directly into the school building.
- Bring curb ramps to ADA compliance and install detectable warning strips.
- Investigate the possibility of moving the street lamp from the ceneter of the sidewalk on the eastern corner of the Union St/School St intersection.
- Study the timing of pedestrian traffic signals at Union/School and Union/Maple; investigate the possibility of offering a WALK signal on a concurrent basis to discourage people from walking against the traffic signal (i.e. when there is a DON'T WALK sign and a gap in traffic).
- Consider installing flashing SCHOOL ZONE beacons on Maple St.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Review parking rules on Union St and potentially limit parking to one side of the street between School St and Mulberry St.
- Increase enforcement of illegal parking on the sidewalks.
- Paint crosswalks across Mulberry St, Ridgewood Terrace, and Ridgewood Place.
- Repaint the crosswalks with a ladder design at the intersection of School St and Union St.
- Monitor traffic speeds along Maple St to validate the need for traffic calming near Milton Bradley.
- Consider installing rumble strips near the curve to alert drivers to the presence of the school zone and traffic signal.
- Post school zone signs in accordance with the school zone standards outlined in the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD).
- Repaint crosswalks at the Maple St/Union St intersection using a ladder or zebra design.
- Replace existing pedestrian signals with countdown signals as funding allows.
- Paint SCHOOL on Maple St and Union St.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Union St, School St, Maple St, Mulberry St
THEMES: Accessibility, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Youth, Schools

SUMMARY:
On November 9, 2015, WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment of Chestnut and Dwight Streets
in the vicinity of the Lincoln Elementary School in Springfield, in partnership with school and municipal
staff and representatives from the Parent Teacher Organization, State Police, Baystate Medical Center
and Pioneer Valley Planning Commission.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add in-pavement "SCHOOL" markings and flashing beacons indicating 20 mph speed limit in school vicinity at the corner of Chestnut St and Harriet St.
- Study feasibility of adding bike facilities on Chestnut St, consistent with "Very High" Level of Bicycle Compatability designated in Springfield's Complete Streets plan.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Paint fog lines on Chestnut St to narrow the width of the travel lanes to 11' as per Massachusetts Highway Department design guidelines.
- Upgrade crosswalks across Chestnut St at Harriet and Cumberland St from standard to ladder design; add in-street pedestrian crossing sign at Harriet St crosswlak and consider raising both crosswalks to enhance pedestrian visibility and slow traffic.
- Add more prominent signage on Chestnut St between Harriet and Cumberland St to further highlight presence of school and pedestrians.
- Add new crosswalks with curb ramps and sidewalk extensions, detectable warning strips, ladder design, and in-street pedestrian crossing signs across Chestnut St at Waverly, Alexander, and Calhoun St.
- Narrow turning radii for traffic turning from Chestnut St onto Jefferson Ave using paint and plastic flexposts.
- Add stop signs with reflective poles on Chestnut St to create a four-way stop at the intersection of Chestnut St with Jefferson Ave and Montmorenci St.
- Upgrade Dwight St intersections at Bancroft and Alexander St by adding new crosswalks with ladder design, curb ramps, detectable warning strips, stop signs, and stop lines.
- Narrow turning radii to slow traffic at the intersection of Dwight St and Jefferson Ave using paint and flexposts.
- Install pedestrian signals at the intersection of Dwight Street and Jefferson Avenue, with push-button activation and leading pedestrian intervals.
- Add new crosswalks with ladder design across Osgood and Brookline Streets at intersections with Dwight Street.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Cumberland St, Chestnut St, Allendale St, Dwight St, Harriet St, Waverly St, Alexander St, Calhoun St, Jefferson Ave, Barcroft St, Brookline Ave
THEMES: Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Bike or Bus, Youth
FACILITATOR\/AUTHOR: Stacey Beuttell, Betsy Johnson, Adi Nochur

SUMMARY: The Brightwood community faces significant challenges with pedestrian safety and access, as 34% of residents lack cars and rely on walking or limited PVTA bus service to reach essential destinations. On November 18, 2015, WalkMass conducted a walk assessment in Brightwood with Springfield municipal staff, MassDOT engineers, and community advocates to evaluate current conditions. The assessment aimed to identify improvements for safer and more accessible pedestrian connections within and beyond the neighborhood.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Construct new, safe pedestrian pathways to connect Brightwood residents to destinations outside the neighborhood, including bus stops and essential services.
- Develop urban pathways across barriers like railroad tracks to improve accessibility.
- Reengineer major streets, such as Plainfield and Birnie Avenue, to include wider sidewalks, grass buffers, and traffic-calming features for enhanced pedestrian safety.
- Collaborate with PVTA to enhance bus service frequency and reliability for Brightwood residents.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Improve pedestrian connections to local bus stops with clear signage and pathways.
- Repair existing sidewalks to address immediate safety concerns and poor walking conditions within the neighborhood.
- Install crosswalks and basic pedestrian safety measures on key routes to West and Main Streets.
- Add “Pedestrian Crossing” signage in high-traffic areas to alert motorists.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Plainfield St, Birnie Ave, &  West St
THEMES: Bike or Bus, Connectivity

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment in the Metro Center neighborhood of Springfield to identify ways to improve the walking connections between downtown businesses on Main Street and the historic neighborhoods and cultural institutions located around the Quadrangle.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Develop a pedestrian scale wayfinding system linking the neighborhoods, museums, and downtown districts
- Revitalize downtown parks and open space, both physically and programmatically, to serve as pedestrian gathering spaces; Pynchon Plaza in particular is a critical link between the museums and downtown
- Continue to study and promote the idea of converting Dwight St and Chestnut St to two-way traffic; their conversion would contribute to traffic calming efforts and promote downtown economic revitalization
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider pedestrian safety improvments on Dwight St and Chestnut St such as painting fog lines, adding curb bump-outs at intersections, and repainting crosswalks with the same red and white color scheme as the downtown district
- Focus on pedestrian infrastructure improvements in the area bounded by Dwight St and Chestnut St to promote connectivity
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Dwight St, Chestnut St, Main St, State St, Falcons Way, Bridge St, Matoon St, Edwards St
THEMES: Connectivity, Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Economic Development

SUMMARY:
Springfield’s South End neighborhood residents, business owners and other stakeholders have been
working to improve safety and to increase investment in the South End for many years. WalkBoston conducted a walk audit on November 16, 2016 to help guide efforts toward neighborhood revitalization and Counter Criminal Continuum (C3) policing strategies.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider hiring a lighting consultant to study current lighting conditions along Main Street and propose strategies to improve lighting with a goal of crime prevention and pedestrian safety
- Reconsider adding curb extensions to shorten crossing distances
- Install a Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacon (RRFB) at the mid-block crosswalk near the Acushnet Ave/Main St intersection
- Consider amending zoning codes and/or site plan design review guidelines to limit the number of driveways and modify parking ratios for businesses along the Main St corridor
- Apply for facade improvement grants or other programs that provide small business owners with funding to reinvest in their property
- Complete the sidewalk on the east side of Main St
- Raise the crosswalk across Locust St to calm traffic and enhance pedestrian visibility
- Study traffic volumes on Main St and mill St to determine if the intersection can be reduced in size, including the removal of the right-turn slip lanes
- Reconstruct the Mill/Locust intersection to include a round-about complete with bicycle and pedestrian facilities
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Use reflective paint on roadways to increase visibility of pavement markings in low light conditions
- Survey the location of light poles and crosswalks; determine if light fixtures can be adjusted
- Discuss lighting strategies and/or incentives for businesses and building owners to keep their lights on at night
- Post advance crosswalk signage
- Consider areas that may need more crosswalks
- Daylight intersections and corners to improve visibility by painting no parking areas within 20' of crosswalks
- Develop concept plan for neighborhood park on vacant land at Main and Adams St
- Work with the city of Springfield to determine responsibility for maintaining streetscape
- Paint fog lines to narrow vehicular travel lanes and calm traffic
- Add high visibility, ladder crosswalks, and ADA compliant curb ramps with detectable warning strips across intersections
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Main St, Locust St, Mill St
THEMES: Accessibility, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: On September 26, 2017, WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment in the Liberty Heights neighborhood of Springfield, with support from the Massachusetts Executive Office of Public Safety and Security (EOPSS) Pedestrian Safety Planning Initiative for High-Fatality Communities. The goal of the walk assessment was to recommend improvements to the local built environment that improve pedestrian safety.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Upgrade pedestrian signals to include countdown clocks and accessibility accommodations
- Consider moving crosswalks back from intersections to shorten crossing distances; requires construction of new curb ramps, repainting crosswalks, stop lines, and right-turn lane arrows
- Install curb bump-outs to shorten crossing distance and prevent cars from parking too close to the crosswalk
- Install Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacons (RRFBs) at mid-block on Carew St
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Adjust signal phasing, possibly by shortening signal cycle to 90 seconds, to prioritize the pedestrian phase to limit wait times for pedestrians; concurrent signals are not recommended in areas of high volumes of fast-moving traffic like on Liberty and Carew St
- Repaint crosswalks with new City standard continental design with next scheduled maintenance
- Install advance crossing signage and curbside crosswalk signage with arrows at crosswalk locations
- Consider placement of in-street pedestrian crossing signs in crosswalks
- Install no parking signs
- Paint diagonal lines or install flex posts within 25' of crosswalks to discourage parking 
- Install curb ramps at missing locations
- Trim vegetation along Carew St
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Carew St, Liberty St
THEMES: Accessibility, Comfort & Safety, Connectivity

SUMMARY:
WalkBoston conducted a walk assessment in the Old Hill neighborhood at the request of Way Finders staff
(formerly HAP Housing) and Springfield’s Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). WalkBoston
is assisting HHS in its implementation of walkability principles throughout Springfield under a CDC grant
known as 1422. The assessment aimed to identify deficient or missing pedestrian infrastructure and make recommendations for improvements while also engaging the community and city staff around issues of a safe walking environment.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install new crosswalks and ADA-compliant curb ramps at intersections identified in neighborhood-wide crosswalk study; upgrade all crossings to include ADA-compliant curb ramps.
- Install accessible pedestrian signals with countdown clocks at each of the signalized intersections along the walking route.
- Consider raised crossings across local streets where they intersect with urban collectors such as Hancock St, Eastern Ave, King St, Alden St, and Union St; drainage patterns need to be evaluated to determine feasibility.
- Work with city staff members to understand sidewalk improvement priorities and schedules for road redesign and maintenance.
- Work with Eversource and city staff and request a lighting study of Old Hill neighborhood to improve light levels at night; the study may yield a recommendation for better light in different locations rather than more lights; the lighting designer's focus should be on the pedestrian experience.
- Monitor clean-up activities and see if positive social pressures to maintain homes, yards, and sidewalks increases.
- Identify locations for new street trees to make urban connectors such as Hancock St and Eastern Ave feel safer and more comfortable for walkers.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Repaint existing crosswalks with enhanced pavement markings such as a continental crosswalk design (Springfield has established continental design as the city crosswalk standard).
- Establish at least one more marked crossing on Hancock St and Eastern Ave.
-Identify locations for new crosswalks neighborhood-wide based on pedestrian use patterns, crash data, and vulnerable populations.
- Install new sidewalks along Orleans St between Union St and Pendleton Ave.
- Complete sidewalk on the west side of Eastern Ave between Greene St and Alden St.
- Shorten the long curb cuts and delineate vehicular entrances to service station along the eastern side of Hancock St and the northern side of Alden St at the Hancock/Alden St intersection.
- Organize a campaign to repair the lights in Barrows Park (contact Eversource).
- Consider a community-based porch light strategy such as regularly leaving porch lights on at night to improve neighborhood light levels.
- Work with the city to better understand maintenance services, street sweeping schedule, and trash receptacle options.
- Maintain existing trees; work with the City Forestry Division to determine maintenance responsibilities and consider a neighborhood Adopt a Tree program if city ordinances allow it.
- Determine if ReGreen Springfield can help fund and plant street trees in Old Hill.
- Identify sidewalks damaged by tree roots, such as on the north side of Alden St near the Alden/Hancock St intersection; use repair strategies that preserve the tree where possible.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Union St, Eastern Ave, Alden St, Hancock St, Pendleton Ave, Tyler St, Orleans St
THEMES: Accessibility, Comfort & Safety, Connectivity, Policy

SUMMARY: The Springfield Union Station Virtual Walk Audit, a pilot for a statewide project led by WalkMass and MassINC with support from the Solomon Foundation, explores connections between social infrastructure and neighborhood resiliency in five Massachusetts Gateway Cities. It aims to promote safer, more enjoyable streets locally and influence state policy for increased investment in these communities. The pilot was conducted through the Massachusetts Department of Public Health’s Mass in Motion Program, which supports community-led healthy living initiatives.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Repurpose underutilized surface parking lots to active uses that are desired by the community (active parks, play equipment, performance space, outdoor street vending).
- Activate open space: Consider strategies for converting some existing passive park space into active-use open spaces. 
- As a part of the tree inventory: In the long term, consider larger, co-befitting projects near the street (e.g. bioswales) or off-street on public property.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Add wayfinding signage: supplement existing downtown maps with large print wayfinding signage for easy navigation between key Metro Center destinations.
- Remove and manage litter.       
- Inventory surface parking lots and assess feasibility of repurposing underutilized lots.
- Review street tree inventory and fill tree pits.
- Assess bike share locations.
- Plan for cultural programming consider partnering with Springfield Culture Partnership to plan events with resident input.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED:
Section 1: 
Dwight St, Bridge St, & Main St

Section 2: 
Taylor St, Chesnut St, & Liberty St
THEMES: Connectivity, Bike or Bus, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Economic Development

SUMMARY:
WalkMass and Way Finders conducted a walk assessment with
Springfield community members as part of the Mass in Motion grant program in the
Upper Hill neighborhood. The goal of the walk audit was to identify areas of
improvement in the built environment, with special focus on ADA compliance issues.
Residents voiced concerns about making Upper Hill a safer, more welcoming
neighborhood for all people, especially for the elderly, children, and people with
mobility issues.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Upgrade Wilbraham/Suffolk signals with countdown pedestrian signals.
- Install bus shelters and enhance park amenities (playground, basketball court, seating).
- Redesign the Roosevelt Ave intersection for safer crossings and remove the right-turn slip lane.
- Add curb extensions and plant more shade trees.
- Implement a lighting strategy for better nighttime pedestrian safety.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Narrow travel lanes on Wilbraham Road with painted parking zones to slow traffic.
- Install a mid-block crosswalk with an RRFB at Norfolk Street for park access.
- Add benches and resting areas; repair damaged sidewalks.
- Post speed limit signs (30mph, 20mph in school zones).
- Remove park bollards and tree stumps; repair park sidewalks.
- Replace pedestrian signage, add advanced stop bars, and repaint crosswalks at Roosevelt Ave.
- Trim vegetation, restrict parking near intersections, and repair sidewalks.
- Plan tree planting and assess nighttime lighting conditions.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Suffolk St, Wilbraham Rd, Carlisle St, Marlborough St, & Intersection of Wilbraham Rd/Roosevelt Ave
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Age Friendly

SUMMARY: The Springfield Roosevelt Ave. Walk Audit, led by WalkMassachusetts in collaboration with WalkBike Springfield, Way Finders, Mass in Motion Springfield, and local residents, assessed pedestrian safety and walkability along a key arterial corridor serving several neighborhoods and schools in Springfield. This project aimed to identify infrastructure needs and advance strategies for safer, more welcoming streets, supporting both immediate local improvements and long-term investment in active transportation. The audit was conducted as part of the Massachusetts Mass in Motion Program, highlighting the importance of community-led healthy living initiatives and advocating for systemic changes to benefit the city’s neighborhoods and schools.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:

The area is vibrant, with restaurants and stores contributing to the community atmosphere. In 2008, the historic Bristol County Courthouse complex underwent an $86 million renovation. While Taunton is car-oriented, the city is promoting walking for healthier lifestyles. The walk audit focused on the area around Morton Hospital, St. Mary’s School, and the intersection of Broadway and Washington Streets, about a quarter mile north of the Taunton Green.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Make the intersection a four-way stop for safety.
- Repaint crosswalks and add signage for pedestrian visibility.
- Add a bump-out on Washington Street to reduce curb radius and speed.
- Add fog lines on N. Pleasant Street to narrow the road and slow traffic.
- Use signs, cones, and tape to delineate pedestrian space during hospital construction.
- Add more signage to alert drivers of pedestrians.
- Narrow the curb radius on the southeast corner with a curb extension.
- Enforce city ordinance for trimming vegetation over sidewalks.
- Add crosswalks at Adams and Church streets.
- Fix uneven sidewalks and add blacktop around standpipe covers.
- Paint ladder design crosswalk at St. Mary’s School.
- Include pedestrian safety measures in Broadway construction.
- Add a signalized crossing at Randall and Broadway.
- Add a curb extension at Randall and Broadway for pedestrian safety.
- Repaint the hospital entrance crosswalk.
- Paint fog lines to reduce street width and speed.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Use temporary signs and cones for pedestrian safety during construction.
- Add crosswalks and signage at Adams and Church streets.
- Repair cracked sidewalks for better walkability.
- Paint temporary crosswalks for visibility.
- Trim vegetation over sidewalks.
- Implement temporary curb extensions at key intersections.

The group conducted an on-the-street audit after discussing key safety concerns and how the assessment would be carried out. The goal was to evaluate pedestrian facilities and identify areas for improvement in walkability and safety.

- Rebuild a wider sidewalk between Dacey Field and the campus, with a grass buffer to separate the walk zone from the roadway.
- Re-engineer the intersection with narrower turning radii to improve pedestrian safety.
- Install electronic radar speed limit signs to calm traffic.
- Add a grass buffer and plant trees to help lower vehicle speeds.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Reduce the effective width of travel lanes by painting a white line 1 foot in from the curb.
- Add a crosswalk and "Children Crossing" signage at the intersection to alert drivers.
- Narrow the width of Winterberry Drive by painting white lines a few feet in from each curb.
- Repaint white fog lines to narrow travel lanes and slow traffic.
- Work with residents to devise alternative mailbox mounting techniques that keep the sidewalk clear.
- Expand the sidewalk with asphalt around utility poles.

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted a walk audit in Ware, MA, focusing on the walkability of a residential neighborhood north of the town center and its connectivity to key areas like senior housing and local services. This audit, part of WalkMass’s Age-Friendly Walking initiative, aims to support the town's Bike and Pedestrian and Complete Streets Prioritization plans. MassDOT data highlights 10 pedestrian-involved crashes in the study area since 2009, including one fatality.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Upgrade pedestrian signals at Main Street intersections to include Accessible Pedestrian Signals (APS) with tactile and audible warnings and countdown WALK signals. Ensure signal phasing allows adequate crossing time for vulnerable users.
- Redesign midblock crossings with bump-outs to shorten crossing distances and improve pedestrian visibility.
- Reconfigure the Main Street and SR-32 intersection to tighten the left-turn radius, slowing vehicle speeds and improving safety for east-west crosswalk users.
- Consider broader alignment changes to improve vehicle turning patterns and prioritize pedestrian safety.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Enhance sidewalk verges by planting street trees in areas with gaps to improve separation from vehicles.
- Replace exposed tree pits with level treatments to prevent tripping hazards for older pedestrians.
- Improve midblock crosswalk visibility by adding in-crosswalk signage or RRFBs and enforcing no-parking zones within 20 feet of crosswalks.
 -Install benches along Main Street to support older adult walking and add wayfinding signage showing walking times to destinations.
- Increase pedestrian-scale lighting on Main Street for nighttime safety.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: North St, Pleasant St, Church St, & SR-32
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Age Friendly
FACILITATOR\/AUTHOR: Stacey Beuttell, Liz Rickley, & LeighAnne Taylor

SUMMARY: WalkBoston, in collaboration with Toole Design Group (TDG), conducted a walk assessment in Watertown, Massachusetts, on November 21, 2014. This assessment was part of the Massachusetts Department of Transportation’s (MassDOT) Bicycle and Pedestrian Safety Awareness and Enforcement Program, which is funded by the Federal Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP). The program involves collaboration among federal, state, regional, and local agencies, along with advocacy groups like MassBike and WalkBoston, aiming to improve pedestrian and cyclist safety in high-crash areas.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Define sidewalk edges with curbing.
- Use different materials or joints to define the sidewalk edge adjacent to parking lots.
- Keep pedestrian access routes clear of street furniture (e.g., hydrants, utility poles), especially the hydrant on Irving Street near Irving Park.
- Provide accessible pedestrian signals and detectors at signalized intersections, including countdown indications, audible tones (e.g., speech messages), vibrotactile walk indicators, pushbutton locator tones, tactile arrows, and vibrating buttons.
- Consider using unique audible tones for each intersection and adjusting tones based on ambient sound levels.
- Position pushbuttons at signalized intersections near curb ramps, away from street furniture.
- Improve access management by reducing the width of and clearly defining large curb cuts.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install detectable warning panels at all curb ramps.
- Provide ADA-compliant curb ramps in a straight path for all crosswalks, minimizing apex ramps.
- Trim vegetation to maintain clear pedestrian access.
-  Repair raised sidewalk panels or patch segments to eliminate tripping hazards.
- Ensure hazard-free pedestrian routes, including detectable warning panels, especially in snow.
- Maintain pedestrian accommodations in work zones.
- Ensure audible pedestrian tones are functioning where available.
- Consider leading pedestrian phases at signalized intersections with concurrent pedestrian phases.
- Repair driveway aprons with potholes in pedestrian paths.
- Install vertical separation between parking areas and sidewalks where missing.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Riverside Street, Irving Street, Mount Auburn Street, & Intersections of North Beacon Street/Irving Street, Arsenal Street/Irving Street, Mount Auburn Street/Irving Street/Palfrey Street, & Mount Auburn Street/Common Street/Parker Street.
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, Accessibility

SUMMARY: After two pedestrian crashes on Elm St occurred on the same day in 2014, one involving the death of a crossing guard, the West Springfield MiM Wellnes Leadership Team (WLT) highlighted safe routes to school at the Coburn School as a priority in the community's Year 1 MiM work plan. In 2016, the Mass in Motion (MiM) Coordinator reached out to Coburn Elementary Principal Shelly St. George to schedule a walk audit in response to concerns about the safety of the walking environment around the school.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider installing Rectangular Rapid Flashing Beacons at the Elm/Garden crossing similar to those found at the US Post Office crossing.
- Work with the police department and engineering department to monitor driving speeds and volumes at the Elm/Garden crossing.
- Study the possibility of re-routing pedestrian traffic away from the rotary at the Main St/Park Ave intersection; changes include removal of RRFB, crosswalk, and sidewalk network leading to the rotary and any improvements should be coordinated with modifications to the Main St/Park St intersection as well.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install curb bump-outs at crosswalk locations to reduce the crossing distances for pedestrians and further discourage drivers from parking near the crosswalks.
- Institute "No Right Turn on Red" for drivers turning right from Westfield St onto Elm St; limiting these turns would allow walkers to feel more comfortable walking across Westfield when traffic is stopped at a red signal.
- Update traffic signal equipment to include pedestrian countdown signals.
- Install crosswalk signs and advance crosswalk signs on Park St and Park Ave to warn drivers of the presence of pedestrians in the crosswalks.
- Study the feasibility and safety of consolidating the un-signalized crosswalks on Park St; consider the path network in the park as it sets up desire lines for people to cross the street.
- Monitor traffic speeds on Park St and Park Ave to ensure drivers are not driving at excessive speeds.
- Consider narrowing or eliminating travel lanes to tighten curb radii, construct curb bump-outs, and slow traffic at both the Elm/Park and Elm St/Park Ave/Union St intersections.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Elm St, Main St, Garden St, Westfield St, Park St, Park Ave, Union St
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety

SUMMARY: WalkBoston conducted a walk audit at Memorial Elementary School and in the surrounding neighborhood to assess the safety and quality of the walking environment for children walking to school. Westfield State University and the Pioneer Valley Planning Commission (PVPC) also completed a walk audit and a Safe Routes to School analysis in the Spring of 2017. The purpose of the WalkBoston audit was to bring town staff together with the school administration to experience the walking conditions in the neighborhood and discuss opportunities to work together to improve pedestrian safety.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Install sidewalk along the southern side of Norman St to facilitate student arrival/dismissal zone.
- Study the impacts of converting Norman St to a one-way street with traffic flowing from Cold Spring Ave to River St during student arrival and dismissal.
- Complete sidewalks on Cold Spring Ave and Allston Ave.
- Define walkway/build sidewalk in front of apartment complex across from Memorial Elementary on Baldwin St.
- Repair/replace/install curb ramps that meet standards including detectable warning strips.
- Inventory existing street trees and propose strategy to plant trees along the neighborhood streets near Memorial School.
- Consider adopting the MA SRTS second grade pedestrian safety curriculum.
- Ask police to conduct regular enforcement activities to help discourage fast driving and enforce school arrival and dismissal policies to protect students.
- Designate priority walking routes near all schools and prioritize these walkways as primary on the snow plow priority map.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Fill in missing sidewalk links at major intersections near Memorial Elementary School that, if improved, could help to encourage mroe students to walk to school.
- Install a stop sign at the Norman St/Cold Spring Ave intersection.
- Paint crosswalks to connect newly installed sidewalks across Cold Spring Rd.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Cold Spring Ave, Baldwin St, Norman St, Heywood Ave, Bosworth St, Windsor St
THEMES: Schools, Comfort & Safety, Weather Control

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted a walk audit in collaboration with the Pioneer Valley Planning Commission and the Mass in Motion program to assess pedestrian needs around Main and Union Streets in West Springfield, a densely populated, diverse residential area. The audit aimed to build on findings from a 2019 Park Access Project that highlighted limited park land in the Merrick neighborhood and inform upcoming infrastructure projects. Recommendations from the audit will guide the Town's planned improvements on Main Street in 2022 and future Union Street upgrades, focusing on enhancing pedestrian and bicycle connections to Memorial Ave and Park Drive.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Implement permanent traffic calming features such as paved curb bump-outs and speed feedback signs to enhance safety.
- Install permanent curb bump-outs and additional pedestrian crossings with safety features like RRFBs and daylighting at key intersections.
- Undertake the necessary studies and planning to permanently establish a protected bike lane on Union Street with an adequate buffer.
- Establish a wayfinding signage program, incorporating community input, to encourage walking to local destinations and enhance pedestrian mobility.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Pilot traffic calming on Main and Union Streets using temporary street furniture such as flex posts and bollards to narrow travel lanes.
- Install pedestrian-activated RRFBs at all existing crosswalks on Main Street to improve pedestrian safety.
- Pilot a protected bike lane on Union Street using quick-build materials like cones and flex posts to assess feasibility.
- Conduct outreach to gather input from residents about local destinations and transportation preferences to inform placemaking efforts.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Main St & Union St
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Bike or Bus

SUMMARY: The Hilltown CDC, in collaboration with Healthy Hampshire and WalkMass, is spearheading a five-year grant project to promote Age-Friendly Walkability in the Hilltown Village Centers. This initiative involves conducting walk audits in partnering Hilltown villages, including Westhampton, to identify infrastructure improvements and policy changes aimed at making village-center walking safer and more enjoyable for all ages. The goal is to enhance pedestrian safety and accessibility, particularly around key community spaces like the Westhampton Public Library, Hampshire Regional High School, and the Westhampton Congregational Church of Christ.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Evaluate and explore improvements to Stage Rd for pedestrians and students and teachers traveling between the school and library.
- Consider installing a crosswalk to connect pedestrians traveling from the Library to the Church and Town Offices and pedestrians walking on South Road.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Increase awareness of pedestrian presence through the use of white shoulder lines on main roads.
- Utilize funding streams through MassDOT and other state agencies to purchase mobile speed feedback signs and place them strategically on the main roads in town. 
- Utilize signage to alert drivers to the presence of a town center and pedestrians.
-Addition of more benches throughout town.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: North and South Rd, Intersection of North Rd and Easthampton/King’s Highway, & Intersection of South Rd and Main Rd
THEMES: Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Youth, Comfort & Safety, Connectivity, Policy
FACILITATOR\/AUTHOR: Zac Churchill, Miranda Briseño, & Stacey Beuttell

SUMMARY: WalkMass worked with Weymouth municipal staff, local residents, and businesspeople under a Healthy Aging grant to conduct walk audits in four commercial districts identified as problematic for senior pedestrian safety: Broad/Washington Streets, Columbian Square, Jackson Square, and Bridge/Green Streets. The audits aimed to identify issues such as discontinuous sidewalks, unsafe crossings, high-speed traffic, and ADA accessibility concerns. The findings led to short- and long-term recommendations for infrastructure improvements to enhance walking safety, emphasizing lower-cost solutions while also suggesting larger investments for sustainable improvements.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Shift curb lines to widen sidewalks, especially on streets with high pedestrian traffic, as part of a larger street reconstruction effort.
- Add flashing "HAWK" signals or pedestrian-activated signals at critical intersections to enhance pedestrian safety.
- Implement a sustained sidewalk upgrading program to address uneven, missing, and poorly maintained sidewalks.
- Ensure ADA-compliant curb ramps are installed and maintained, with necessary sidewalk widening and re-grading.
- Provide crosswalks at all bus stops, ensuring safe pedestrian routes to and from public transportation.
- Review and adjust signal timing at intersections to optimize pedestrian safety, ensuring appropriate WALK signals and adequate crossing time.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Implement low-cost improvements at Columbian Square, such as place-making strategies to create a pedestrian-friendly environment, with the support of landscape designers and planners.
- Add better-marked and regulated pedestrian crossings in several locations at Broad/Washington Streets to address safety issues, particularly for seniors.
- Narrow lane widths on wide streets by painting fog lines, adding bike lanes, and incorporating on-street parking to slow down traffic.
- Tighten turning radii at intersections using paint, temporary bollards, or asphalt curbs to improve pedestrian safety.
- Re-paint crosswalks with reflective ladder or zebra striping and adjust signal timing to provide more WALK time for pedestrians.
- Add in-street pedestrian crossing signs, curb extensions, and prohibit parking within 20-30 feet of crosswalks for improved visibility.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Bridge St, Sea St, North St, Jackson Sq,  Broad St, & Washington St
THEMES: Comfort & Safety, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Bike or Bus

SUMMARY:
WalkBoston conducted a walkability workshop on April 15, 2016, funded by the Massachusetts
Department of Public Health Mass in Motion program. The workshop discussed the principles of
walkable communities and summarized pedestrian infrastructure improvements that increase safety and
improve the quality of the walking environment. This walk audit was part of the town's effort to address healthy aging through healthy community design.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Work with the police on periodic enforcement of village speed limits using both speed trailers and officer patrols.
- Install Rectangular Rapid Flash Beacons (RRFBs) on Route 9.
- Review the Town of Williamsburg curb cut permitting rules and revise to minimize the frequency and the width of curb cuts; work with property owners along the Route 9 study area to reduce the width of curb cuts.
- Identify areas where plantings, trees, and benches could be added along the corridor to replicate the street treatment on the south side of Route 9 in front of historic properties and general stores.
- Conduct a parking study to determine the existing supply and pent up demand in the Burgy village center.
- Work with the business owners to better understand the parking issues they wrestle with and consider adopting a shared parking strategy for the village center.
- Direct sidewalk maintenance and reconstruction funds to making improvements on priority routes
- Study the traffic pattern at the N Main St/North St/E Main St intersection to determine if a 4-way stop would improve safety.
- Continue the planning of a proposed walking trail along the Mill River behind Florence Bank and Williamsburg Market.
- Increase programming in the public open spaces to increase use and attachment to the village green spaces and center.
- Consider further study of access and circulation to public green spaces.
- Establish a municipally recognized bicycle/pedestrian committee or task force. 
- Draft and adopt a complete streets policy to qualify for the MassDOT Complete Streets Funding program.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Introduce clues that vehicles are entering the village center such as village center signage, sculptures, or other public art.
- Investigate the possibility of narrowing travel lanes by changing location of fog lines along Route 9.
- Enhance pedestrian road crossings with advance crosswalk signage and more robust crosswalk painting (ladder or continental design).
- Reprogram or repair school zone flashing beacon to operate when school is in session and at peak arrival and dismissal times; investigate the possibility of installing a second school zone pavement marking before the crosswalk.
- Place an in-street pedestrian sign in crossings permanently.
- Consider shortening the curb radii at corners and intersections to reduce crossing distance and calm turning traffic.
- Consider formalizing the parking space layout in and around Florence Bank, Williamsburg Market, and Cichy's Garage; delineate a pedestrian zone where drivers can expect people walking across the parking lot driveways.
- Identify priority walking routes; priority walking routes may include connections to schools, senior housing, residential neighborhoods, parks, trailheads, or walking loops.
- Paint crosswalks across N Main St; study the safety implications of painting a crosswalk across North St on the south side off the intersection where no stop sign exists currently.
- Highlight public green spaces on walking loop maps; maps could be made available in the library, post office, and local retail establishments.
- Consider signage program to direct residents and visitors to local landmarks and parks.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Route 9, North St, Petticoat Hill Rd, South St, N Main St, E Main St
THEMES: "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Bike or Bus, Connectivity, Policy

SUMMARY: WalkMass conducted a walk audit in Williamstown, MA, as part of its Age-Friendly Walking initiative aimed at improving walking conditions in rural and gateway communities of Massachusetts. The audit focused on the walkability of SR-2, both on the Williams College campus and near the town’s main shopping plaza, highlighting areas with pedestrian-involved crashes. MassDOT's data shows 11 pedestrian crashes in the area since 2014, with two involving pedestrians over 75, though none were fatal.
LONG TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Consider relocating midblock crosswalks at Southworth Street and First Congregational Church for better visibility and safety.
- Implement automated pedestrian detection devices for RRFBs in high-use areas, potentially replacing push-button activation.
- Work with Williams College to standardize bench types and locations, ensuring proper accessibility and comfort for all pedestrians.
- Explore the addition of pedestrian refuge islands at the SR-2 and Water Street intersection for better safety and a shorter crossing distance.
- Evaluate the feasibility of extending pedestrian-scale lighting to all critical crosswalk locations for improved visibility in low light conditions.
- Implement a full reconstruction of sidewalks with proper grading and verge additions to improve overall walkability and safety.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:
- Evaluate and improve sight lines for midblock crosswalks at Southworth Street and near First Congregational Church.
- Install in-crosswalk signage or RRFB at the Southworth Street crosswalk.
- Add benches in wide verge areas along SR-2 to increase comfort for pedestrians.
- Update pavement markings at the SR-2 and Cole Avenue intersection to continental striping for better visibility.
- Repair sidewalk cracks and improve grading to address steep cross-slopes and provide better pedestrian conditions.
- Improve pedestrian-scale lighting along SR-2, focusing on high-traffic areas, and around campus.
STREETS, INNTERSECTIONS + AREA COVERED: Park St, SR-2, & Intersection of Park St/Cole Ave
THEMES: Schools, "Traffic Calming, Speed, Safety ", Comfort & Safety, Age Friendly

The goal of these assessments is to improve safety for students walking or biking to school, ensuring there are safe routes for increased walking and biking activity.

- Extend the curb on Beach Street to improve visibility for pedestrians crossing from east to west, using paint and flexible delineators.
- Limit curb cuts at the gas station to two smaller access points or define the pedestrian right of way more clearly with bold white parallel lines.
- Re-establish the sidewalk and maintain a clear walking path along Salem Street.
- Mark a crosswalk that connects the two ramps at a specific driveway to remind drivers of pedestrian presence.
- Install an accessible curb ramp at the east side of the school driveway to ensure smooth access to the school entrance.
SHORT TERM RECOMMENDATIONS:

- Improve the crosswalk at Salem Street, Hilltop Terrace, and Sedgwick to ensure pedestrian safety when crossing.
- Re-align the crosswalk at the driveway to connect two curb ramps rather than a curb ramp and a driveway.
- Determine if the driveway should be one-way or two-way and install the appropriate signage and pavement markings.
